Certainly! Let's start with the active comparator for the adaptive phenotypes. This group will consist of the Adaptive-A and Adaptive-B subgroups. Participants will be administered Dupilumab (Dupixent), an interleukin-4 receptor alpha antagonist. They will also be exposed to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The goal is to evaluate the efficacy of Dupilumab in individuals with adaptive phenotypes.

The experimental group for maladaptive phenotypes will also be divided into Maladaptive-A and Maladaptive-B subgroups. Participants in this group will receive Dupilumab (Dupixent) and undergo exposure to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The purpose is to assess the effectiveness of Dupilumab in individuals with maladaptive phenotypes and compare the treatment response between adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes.

The placebo comparator arms will mirror the adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes. Participants in the Adaptive-A and Adaptive-B subgroups will receive an inert placebo instead of the active drug but will still be exposed to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The same applies to the Maladaptive-A and Maladaptive-B subgroups. These arms are important for establishing a baseline response in adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes when not receiving the active drug.

Instead of 'piece-mealing' the lesions with a diathermic snare, the entire lesion will be excised circumferentially with a resection basket. I would also suggest using a high-output submucosal irrigation system in this arm to improve hemostasis. This type of system delivers physiological fluid, oxygen, and CO2 to the submucosal tissue during the EMR procedure. The flow rate of the system can be adjusted to maintain the submucosal tissue at a temperature of 39°C throughout the procedure to help avoid submucosal nerve injury and pain. These two arms will each have a follow up endoscopy 3 months after the procedure to evaluate for any recurrence of lesions. This involves an initial submucosal injection of physiological solution and methylene blue, followed by 'piece-meal' resection using a 10 or 15 millimeter diathermic snare and ablation of the margins with the snare tip. This arm will serve as a comparison to evaluate the conventional hot EMR technique.

For the experimental arm, I suggest using the Cold EMR technique. This involves an initial submucosal injection of physiological solution and methylene blue, followed by 'piece-meal' resection using a dedicated cold snare. This technique is hypothesized to have advantages such as reduced thermal injury and potentially lower recurrence rates. By comparing this arm to the hot EMR arm, you can determine if the cold EMR technique is a feasible alternative for large colonic adenomas.

Study Population: Patients with lumbar disc herniation at L4-L5 with or without radiculopathy
Nucleus Replacement vs. Traditional Discectomy
Intervention: Patients in the Nucleus Replacement group receive the PerQdisc® Nucleus Replacement System, a minimally invasive surgical procedure in which the degenerated or herniated disc is replaced with a collagen barrier matrix that acts as a scaffold for the expansion and growth of the patient's own natural disc cells. Secondary Outcome Measures: Patients will be evaluated for changes in the Neck and Low Back Disability Index (NFLD), Quality of Life (EuroQol-5D and the SF-12), and complications such as opioid use, incidence of re-operation, and serious adverse events identified using Form FDA 3500.

Thank you for providing all the necessary information. Based on the details you've given, I would suggest the following study arms:

1. Experimental: Dose Escalation: VVD-130850 Single Agent
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants receiving ascending doses of VVD-130850 as a single agent.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Participants will take VVD-130850 orally once daily in 21-day treatment cycles during the dose escalation phase.
   - Reasoning: This study arm is necessary to determine the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of VVD-130850 as a single agent in participants with advanced solid and hematologic tumors. By escalating the doses, researchers can establish the maximum tolerated dose and assess any potential side effects.

2. Experimental: Dose Escalation: VVD-130850 + Pembrolizumab Combination Therapy
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants receiving ascending doses of VVD-130850 in combination with pembrolizumab.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Participants will take VVD-130850 orally once daily and receive pembrolizumab intravenously every 3 weeks in 21-day treatment cycles during the dose escalation phase.
   - Reasoning: This study arm is designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and potential synergistic effects of combining VVD-130850 with pembrolizumab in participants with advanced solid and hematologic tumors. It aims to determine the optimal dose of the combination therapy for further investigation.

3. Experimental: Dose Expansion: VVD-130850 Single Agent
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants receiving VVD-130850 at the recommended dose for expansion (RDE) as a single agent.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Participants will take VVD-130850 orally once daily in 21-day treatment cycles during the dose expansion phase.
   - Reasoning: This study arm aims to further evaluate the safety and efficacy of VVD-130850 at the recommended dose determined from the dose escalation phase. It allows for a larger group of participants to receive the drug at the established dose to gather more data on its effects.

4. Experimental: Dose Expansion: VVD-130850 + Pembrolizumab Combination Therapy
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants receiving VVD-130850 at the recommended dose for expansion (RDE) in combination with pembrolizumab.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Participants will take VVD-130850 orally once daily and receive pembrolizumab intravenously every 3 weeks in 21-day treatment cycles during the dose expansion phase.
   - Reasoning: This study arm is crucial for assessing the safety, tolerability, and potential anti-tumor activity of the combination therapy at the recommended dose for expansion. It allows for a larger cohort of participants to receive the combination treatment and provides more robust data on its efficacy.

groundtruth: Thank you for providing those details. Now, let's move on to designing the study arms. We have three treatment modalities: extracorporeal shock wave therapy, ultrasound, and dexamethasone iontophoresis.

For the extracorporeal shock wave group, we can assign patients with lateral epicondylitis to this arm. The intervention would be a physiotherapy program consisting of hot packs, TENS, stretching, and eccentric strengthening exercises. Additionally, they would receive 3 sessions of ESWT at 1.8 bar, 10.0 Hz, 2000 beats once a week for 3 weeks. This would be in addition to the ten-day physiotherapy program. What do you think?

For the ultrasound group, we can also assign patients with lateral epicondylitis. The intervention would be the same physiotherapy program as the extracorporeal shock wave group. Additionally, they would receive ultrasound therapy at 1.5 watt/cm2 in continuous mode to the painful area for 5 minutes, 5 days a week for two weeks. This would be in addition to the ten-day physiotherapy program. How does that sound?

For the dexamethasone iontophoresis group, we can assign patients with lateral epicondylitis. The intervention would be the same physiotherapy program as the other groups. Additionally, they would receive dexamethasone iontophoresis therapy for 10 days. In each session, 0.1% dexamethasone ophthalmic pomade would be applied to the anodal electrode and placed on the lateral epicondyle. Galvanic current would be applied at 0.1-0.2 milliampere/cm2. This would also be in addition to the ten-day physiotherapy program. What do you think?

Great! Now, let me summarize the full study arms:

Study Arms:
1. Extracorporeal shock wave group:
   - Participant Group/Arm: Patients with lateral epicondylitis who will receive extracorporeal shock wave therapy.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Patients in this group will undergo a physiotherapy program consisting of hot packs, TENS, stretching, and eccentric strengthening exercises. Additionally, they will receive 3 sessions of ESWT at 1.8 bar, 10.0 Hz, 2000 beats once a week for 3 weeks.

The inclusion criteria for this trial include being at least 18 years old, having relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma (meeting IMWG 2016 diagnostic criteria), and being frail according to the IMWG frailty assessment. Patients should have relapsed after previous treatment with 1-3 regimens and be unresponsive or unable to undergo autologous stem cell transplantation. Additionally, patients should have reached measurable levels of serum monoclonal protein (M protein) or other indicators. The patient's clinical indicators must also meet certain criteria. These are some of the main inclusion criteria. Is there anything specific you would like to clarify or add?

The exclusion criteria for this trial include patients with newly diagnosed multiple myeloma, previous use of pomalidomide or cyclophosphamide, and patients with allergies or intolerance to cyclophosphamide or dexamethasone. Patients with active hepatitis B, hepatitis C, or other immunodeficiency diseases are also excluded. Additionally, patients with severe thrombotic events, uncontrolled or severe cardiovascular disease, and recent major surgeries are not eligible for the trial. Patients with certain mental or physical illnesses that may interfere with participation are also excluded. These are some of the main exclusion criteria. How were the study arms determined? [START] For each arm/group, we first considered the intervention(s) to be delivered. Then, for each intervention(s), we considered who would receive it/them (i.e., participant population) and how it would be administered (e.g., in person, written material, etc.). For example, the Shared Medical Decision-Making intervention would be offered to all participants in the Intervention Group. We explored several possibilities and discussed them until we arrived at an arm allocation plan that we felt was feasible and acceptable, taking into account practical and ethical considerations (e.g., there may be logistical challenges in delivering a treatment intervention only via video/phone for some population groups, there may be insufficient staffing or participant interest in implementing a particular approach, and so on).  We included all of the intervention(s) and control(s) that made it through this process and were logistically feasible, even if one or more might be deemed more or less attractive or promising than others.  We then chose an arm-group allocation scheme that seemed most appropriate to the research question. For example, if the aim/hypothesis were only modestly interesting insofar as to see if the Shared Medical Decision-Making intervention is feasible, we would include only the Intervention Group (Shared Decision-Making+Provider guidance) as we wanted to keep the design as simple as possible. In this example, the study would be a 2-arm crossover (or perhaps better a 3-arm crossover with the addition of a control group receiving no Shared Decision-Making intervention) RCT with the control being a form of usual care-plus-patient's existing decision-making. Certainly. The intervention will involve the following steps. First, a thorough ultrasound examination of the gallbladder will be done to confirm the diagnosis and identify any stones that need to be removed. Then, the doctor will insert a flexible tube (catheter) through the mouth and into the stomach and duodenum (food pipe) to reach the area of the gallbladder. Through this tube, a special instrument (endoscope) will be inserted to inflate the gallbladder and visualize the stones. The doctor will use a high-frequency ultrasound device at the end of the endoscope to break the stones up into smaller pieces. The broken stones will then be removed or left to pass through the duodenum. This procedure can be done on an outpatient basis or as an emergency intervention. It's important to note that the presence of gallstones and the severity of symptoms will dictate the need for endoscopic therapy versus a scheduled surgery. The intervention for this arm will involve an endoscopic gallbladder drainage under EUS guidance using lumen apposing metal stents (LAMS) followed, when needed, by endoscopic lithotripsy.

Absolutely. For the intervention, access to the gallbladder will be performed from the stomach or duodenum using a LAMS with an electrocautery-enhanced delivery system such as Hot Axios or Hot Spaxus. The size of the stent used will depend on the size of the largest gallstone, with a 10 mm diameter stent used for gallstones smaller than 10 mm and a larger diameter (≥15 mm stent) used for gallstones larger than 10 mm. Additionally, if needed, colecystoscopy lithotripsy will be performed using mechanical lithotripsy and/or laser lithotripsy. The first cholecystoscopy will be done 2 weeks after the initial procedure.

A stent of 10 mm in diameter will be used if the largest gallstone will be smaller than 10 mm in size while a greater diameter (≥15 mm stent) will be used if the largest gallstone will be larger than 10mm. Colecystoscopy lithotripsy will be performed, when needed, using mechanical lithotripsy and/or laser lithotripsy at the discretion of the endoscopist. First cholecystoscopy will be done 2 weeks after the index procedure.

Excellent. Now that we have all the necessary information, let's design the study arms. Based on the details you provided, I suggest the following arms:

1. Experimental: real-rTMS
Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes individuals at risk for Alzheimer's disease who will undergo real repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) sessions.
Intervention/Treatment: The intervention involves 4 daily 25-minute high-frequency rTMS sessions over one week using a 70-mm figure-eight coil at 20Hz. Target localization will be performed with a stereotaxic neuronavigation system.
Reasoning: This arm is essential to test the efficacy of non-invasive stimulation techniques, specifically real rTMS, in modulating the default mode network (DMN) in individuals at risk for Alzheimer's disease. By targeting this specific population with a known genetic risk factor for AD, the study aims to assess the potential benefits of this intervention in early stages of the disease.

2. Sham Comparator: sham-rTMS
Participant Group/Arm: This arm serves as the control group in the study.
Intervention/Treatment: Participants in this arm will undergo 4 daily 25-minute sham-rTMS sessions over one week, where the sham condition will mimic the real rTMS protocol but with a sham coil.
Reasoning: The inclusion of a sham comparator arm is crucial to establish the efficacy of the real rTMS intervention. By comparing the outcomes of the experimental arm with the control arm, researchers can determine whether the observed effects are due to the specific intervention or simply a placebo effect. This design helps ensure the validity and reliability of the study results.

Patients who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria will undergo laparoscopic radical antegrade modular pancreatosplenectomy (LRAMPS) surgery. This arm is necessary to compare the outcomes of patients undergoing LRAMPS with those undergoing LDP. The LRAMPS procedure involves the removal of Gerota's fascia and perirenal fat capsule, with the option to perform anterior or posterior LRAMPS depending on the resection of the left adrenal gland. The removal of specific lymph nodes is also outlined based on the tumor location.

Study Arm 2:
Participant Group/Arm: LDP group
Intervention/Treatment: Procedure: LDP
Patients who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria will undergo laparoscopic distal pancreatosplecnectomy (LDP) surgery. This arm is essential to compare the outcomes of patients undergoing LDP with those undergoing LRAMPS. The LDP procedure involves dissection behind the fusion fascia and the removal of specific lymph nodes based on the tumor location. This arm allows for a comparison of outcomes between LDP and LRAMPS in the context of early-stage left-sided pancreatic cancer.

ACRONYM = Acute study of Cognitively assisted Robot therapy to enhance Arm and hand performance AFTER stroke; Efficacy to support Clinical practice ACRT-ACUTE-2 is a double-blind, multicenter, randomized parallel-group, 90-day active treatment, 90-day extinction-maintenance phase, phase II, double dummy, parallel group, pragmatic, clinically adaptive, multicenter, active and sham rTMS versus an active and sham TMS plus education comparison trial. ACRT=Arm and Hand Rehabilitation using the neuroSkyTM Robot device and Virtual REality for Stroke Survivors-2 THEORY This is a prospective, double-blinded, single-center, crossover, repeated-measures, randomized trial assessing the efficacy of Robotic Assisted Wearable ExosuitTM (RAWEx) in reducing energy expenditure and enhancing movement economy during level walking over a range of walking velocities. Target Population The target clinical population is individuals with lower limb motor deficits resulting from chronic stroke. Clinical Rehabilitation Testing. The study subjects will be recruited from referrals of post- Stroke adults seeking to improve their gait and mobility. This study consists of two parallel groups. Both groups will wear an RAWEx suit and perform overground walking under three experimental conditions at three velocities for four days per week for one week. The order of the three conditions will be randomized across subjects ﬁxed for the full study. Assessments: We will use indirect calorimetry to measure the oxygen and CO 2 exchange between the subject and the environment to determine resting energy expenditure as well as during walking at walking speed conditions. We will measure the amount of oxygen consumed by the participant wearing the RAWEx suit while they walk, and by the participant wearing the control suit while the RAWEx suit is worn. We will also measure heart rate during the walking tasks. In addition, we will use actigraphy and a Berg motion sensor to analyze the power output.
This study is a prospective, randomized, blinded study designed to compare the functional abilities of neurobotic® Lokomotion
groundtruth: Since this is a single-group assignment study, we won't have a control group. We'll focus solely on evaluating the effects of Ekso mediated gait training. However, this design decision may limit our ability to compare the intervention to other treatment approaches. It's worth considering incorporating a control group in future studies for a more comprehensive evaluation.

Yes, it's important to note that during the Ekso mediated gait training sessions, the therapist will guide the participant's progress using a specific plan. The therapist will set a trajectory for each leg, determining the appropriate step height and length, and program it into the Ekso device. As the participant improves, the therapist will gradually reduce the assistance provided until the participant reaches a point where they no longer require assistance or reach a plateau. In the final phase, the participant will walk using their own movements, with the therapist adding resistance or assistance based on their needs. This approach allows for personalized and progressive training.

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: Ekso mediated gait training
- Participant Group/Arm: Participants undergoing Ekso mediated gait training twice per week for 8 weeks.
- Intervention/Treatment: The use of the Ekso Robotic Eksoskeleton during each treatment session, providing high repetition and intensity training. Reasoning: Including a control group that receives standard monitoring methods allows for comparison with the ctDNA dynamic monitoring approach. This arm helps evaluate the effectiveness and superiority of ctDNA monitoring in predicting recurrence of ovarian cancer after primary treatments.

In the experimental RMT group, the 16 patients will receive a loading dose of RMT capsules containing approximately 5 x 10^11 bacteria on day 1, followed by a daily dose of 2 x 10^11 bacteria for 6 days. The RMT capsules should be self-administered on an empty stomach with at least one glass of water. Clear liquids are allowed, and food can be resumed 2 hours after administration.

In the placebo comparator group, participants will receive identical looking placebo capsules daily for 7 days. On day 1, they will receive 5 placebo capsules, followed by 2 placebo capsules daily from Day 2-7. The placebo capsules should also be self-administered on an empty stomach with at least one glass of water. Clear liquids are allowed, and food can be resumed 2 hours after administration.

In studies involving an intervention, there are commonly three phases of the trial: Phase I is the dose ranging trial, where the dosage and efficacy of the treatment regimen is defined. Phase II is the confirmatory trial, involving a larger patient population, to confirm the findings of phase I. Phase III is the definitive trial, aiming to look at effects of the treatment in more detail, and to look at longer term effects. Rationale: Nocturnal continuous positive airway pressure therapy is the gold standard treatment for symptomatic OSA. It provides positive pressure via a nasal or oronasal mask to prevent upper airway collapse during sleep. This study arm is essential to assess the efficacy of CPAP therapy in treating obstructive sleep apnea. By initiating CPAP therapy and then withdrawing it for a short period, we can evaluate the acute and long-term effects of CPAP on physiological parameters in patients with moderate to severe OSA. 1. Active Comparator: Caries treatment
Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes patients who undergo caries treatment only.
Intervention/Treatment: The patients in this group receive caries treatment, and the aerobic bacterial content in the dental office air is evaluated using the Koch sedimentation method. Microbiological analysis is conducted after the caries treatment.

2. Active Comparator: Caries treatment and fumigation
Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes patients who undergo both caries treatment and fumigation.

Please let me know if you have any questions or if you'd like to make any changes to the study arms.

The first study arm serves as a control group to compare the bacterial levels in the dental office environment before and after any intervention (fumigation). By analyzing the bacterial content after caries treatment alone, we can assess the impact of fumigation specifically on bacterial reduction, independent of any other treatment effects.

The second study arm allows us to assess the combined impact of caries treatment and fumigation on bacterial levels in the dental office environment. By comparing the bacterial content before and after both interventions, we can determine if fumigation, in addition to caries treatment, leads to a significant reduction in bacterial levels. This arm helps evaluate the effectiveness of fumigation as an additional measure to reduce bacterial contamination in dental offices.

Choose an outcome for the superiority trial 2. Choose an equipoise-generating noninferiority margin for the noninferiority trial 3. Determine the sample sizes for superiority and noninferiority trials 4. Collect data and analyze the trial 1. Choose an outcome for the superiority trial It depends on what the sponsor wants to tell the world at the end of the day, but the most likely candidate is Oxygen saturation of arterial blood (O2 Sat). The best way to measure O2 Sat is by using pulse oximetry. SpO2 is a great, but it is not the best measure of O2 Sat, because it only looks at two parameters of oxygenation, rather than the total oxygen content of arterial blood. 2. Choose an equipoise-generating noninferiority margin In high-risk patients scheduled for GI endoscopy, what is the clinically relevant noninferiority difference in O2 Sat between nasal CPAP and nasal cannula oxygen? It is often agreed upon that a difference of less than 5% is clinically insignificant and that a difference of at least 10% is worth publishing. This difference also depends on what level of oxygenation is required for a task (i.e., sleep vs. GI endoscopy). 3. Determine the sample sizes for superiority and noninferiority trials In a superiority trial, based on a power of 0.80 and a noninferiority margin of 5%, the sample size is ~523 patients in each arm and ~3-5 years of follow-up. Study Name: Bicondoler, "Empowered Relief: a randomized controlled trial of remote, psychoeducational pain skills training for chronic pain management delivered via Zoom"
PI: Dr. Michelle Bicondor
1. Research Question/Aim: To examine the efficacy of a remote (e.g., online) psychoeducational group, Empowered Relief (ER), in reducing pain and improving quality of life in adults with chronic pain.
2. Intervention/Treatment: Participants will have psychoeducation about pain neuroscience via Zoom and be offered the opportunity to practice and receive coaching on coping skills via Zoom.
3. Expected Results: The primary outcome, pain severity, will be assessed monthly for 3 months, and the secondary outcomes (e.g., depression, sleep, function) will be assessed at baseline and 3-, 6-, and 12- month follow-up.
4. Target Population: Adults aged 18 and older, diagnosed with chronic pain for at least 3 months, with pain of a sufficient intensity to interfere with their ability to cope with daily life.
If you have more information about the inclusion and exclusion criteria, how the data will be collected, and a study timeline, please include that information here.
Participants must be 18 or older and have a chronic pain condition that has been present at a sufficient intensity (i.e, interfering with daily function) for more than 3 months. Exclusion criteria include the following: an inability or unwillingness to complete surveys online, psychosocial conditions such as major depression or bipolar disorder, and cognitive decline as measured by impaired or inaccessible Mini-Mental State Exam (MMSE) ≥18.

For participant inclusion, you could consider stable angina pectoris, unstable angina pectoris, or individuals who have passed the acute phase of myocardial infarction. The age requirement should be set at 18 years or older, and written informed consent is essential. Additionally, participants should have intermediate coronary lesions with diameter stenosis ranging from 30% to 80% as estimated by visual examination from coronary angiography.

Participants should be excluded if they are ineligible for diagnostic IVUS or FFR examination, have undergone prior coronary artery bypass grafting of the interrogated vessels, experienced myocardial infarction within 72 hours of coronary angiography, or have severe heart failure. Serum creatinine levels greater than 150 umol/L or glomerular filtration rates below 45 ml/kg/1.73 m2 should also be considered exclusions. Furthermore, individuals with allergies to the contrast agent or adenosine, life expectancy of less than 2 years, IVUS pullback that does not cover the entire lesion, or severe myocardial bridge in the interrogated vessel should be excluded from the study.

Based on the information you provided, I suggest having two study arms. The first arm will focus on pressure wire-based fractional flow reserve (FFR) as the participant group. The intervention/treatment for this arm should be the diagnostic test: fractional flow reserve (FFR). This arm is necessary as FFR is a well-established standard reference for assessing the functional significance of coronary artery stenosis. By using pressure wire-based FFR as a comparison, we can evaluate the accuracy of the new diagnostic test, ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR).

The second study arm should involve participants who will undergo intravascular ultrasound (IVUS)-based ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR). The intervention/treatment for this arm should be the diagnostic tests: ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) and intravascular ultrasound (IVUS). This arm is important as it focuses on the new diagnostic test, UFR, which is the main intervention being evaluated in this trial. By combining UFR with IVUS, we aim to assess the functional significance of coronary artery stenosis in a more comprehensive manner. The use of IVUS will provide detailed imaging of the coronary vessels, enhancing the accuracy of UFR calculations.

groundtruth: The intervention involves the use of ICI201, which is an investigational drug being evaluated in this trial. It is a CAR-T cell therapy that specifically targets GPRC5D, a protein expressed on the surface of multiple myeloma cells. By targeting this protein, ICI201 aims to selectively kill multiple myeloma cells while sparing normal cells.

Certainly! The ICI201 CAR-T cell injection involves genetically modifying the patient's own T cells to express a chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) that specifically targets GPRC5D. These modified CAR-T cells are then infused back into the patient's body. Once inside, they can recognize and destroy multiple myeloma cells that express GPRC5D. This personalized approach harnesses the patient's immune system to target and eliminate cancer cells.

Intervention Description: Connect-Home Plus will be delivered in the skilled nursing facility and via telephone after discharge. It will introduce organizational structure to support delivery of transitional care processes, including the use of electronic health record (EHR) templates, Connect-Home Plus Toolkit, and staff training. The intervention will consist of two steps. In Step 1, SNF nurses, therapists, and social workers will develop a Transition Plan of Care and prepare the patient and caregiver to manage the illness and functional needs. In Step 2, a dementia caregiving specialist will make three calls to the patient's home within 30 days of discharge. The intervention will focus on key care needs such as home safety, symptom management, medication reconciliation, function and activity, and coordination of follow-up medical care.

Sure, here are the details: The purpose of the study is to compare the effect of flow-controlled ventilation with pressure-controlled ventilation during robotic surgery. A total of 200 American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status Grade I and II patients aged 18 years or older, undergoing elective robot-assisted laparoscopic surgery with an expected duration of 90 minutes or more will be enrolled at three centers. Exclusion criteria include prior history of pulmonary disease or surgery, as well as abnormal lung or cardiac function. The flow-controlled group will receive continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) from the Ventinova Medical EVONE device that allows positive-pressure ventilation with a variable flow. Patients will be randomly assigned to the flow-controlled arm using computer-generated serial allocation with block sizes of 8, 12, 16, or 20, stratified by center. The active comparator group will receive mechanical ventilation with a Dräger Medical Atlan A350 machine using the usual pressurized mode. Study-related devices will be used by mask, and all parameters such as FiO 2 and minute ventilation will be managed according to the institutional normal protocols for robotic surgery. Primary outcome is intraoperative respiratory adverse events. Secondary outcomes include postoperative complications, pulmonary and cardiac function, and hospital stay. The flow-controlled group will receive CPAP from the Ventinova Medical EVONE device that allows for positive-pressure ventilation with a variable flow
Study Protocol for Flow-Controlled Ventilation Versus Pressure-Controlled Ventilation for Mechanical Ventilation During Robot-Assisted Laparoscopic Surgery: A Randomized Clinical Trial.

Study Arm 2: Hypothetical intervention Based on recent studies showing a relationship between the success of intrauterine insemination and post-wash total motile sperm count, we hypothesize that a higher post-wash total motile sperm count results in a higher pregnancy rate. We want to test this hypothesis by giving intrauterine insemination to patients with low post-wash total motile sperm count, and comparing the pregnancy rate in this group to the pregnancy rate of the standard study arm. This group will represent what happens if we were to increase the sperm count in the insemination procedure.
This group will help us assess the impact of post-wash TMSC > 3 x 10^6 on the success of intrauterine insemination.

Study Arm 3: Intrauterine insemination with pre-wash TMSC <3 x 10^6. The Intervention/treatment is the same as study arm 2, but the pre-wash total motile sperm count is below the recommended threshold of 3 x 10^6.

This arm is designed to evaluate the pregnancy rates of patients with a low post-wash total motile sperm count in accordance with current guidelines, as a basis for further study and possible revision of the recommended threshold. The lower the post-wash TMSC, the more likely that assisted reproductive technology will be required to achieve a pregnancy, and the higher the rate of multiple births will be.  The implications for policy and practice are clear, thus the need to include a patient population with a post-wash TMSC less than 3 x 10^6 for assessment of pregnancy rates at that threshold.

Study 1: Treatment effects The control group receives standard clinical practice, while the two study groups receive the experimental treatment. 1 Study 2: Treatment effect versus underlying disease/covariate The control and treatment groups are the same as in Study 1. 2 Study 3: Treatment effect versus crossover Since Study 1 and Study 2 are similar, only the differences between Study 1 and Study 3 need to be described. Pre- to post-treatment change: Patients assigned to the treatment group are treated with the experimental treatment, so the change between the two assessments is due to the treatment. Within-subjects covariate: Patients in the control group are "crossovered" into the treatment group so they are still being treated the standard way while the treatment group is receiving the experimental treatment. The within-subjects covariate of interest is the previous baseline measurement for the patients in the control group. The within-subjects crossover design prevents this group of patients from being compared with themselves. Crossover: The within-subjects covariate is a factor that is fixed over time, so any repeated measures are the covariate for themselves.

   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm consists of patients who will receive standard care, including sedation and targeted temperature management (TTM) for at least 24-48 hours post-cardiac arrest.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The control group will not undergo early cessation of sedation and TTM, as per standard care protocols.
   - Reasoning: This arm serves as a comparison group to evaluate the impact of early cessation of sedation and TTM in the experimental group. By having a control group receiving standard care, the study can determine if the experimental intervention leads to better outcomes compared to the standard approach. This arm helps establish the baseline for comparison and provides valuable insights into the potential benefits of early weaning from ICU treatment.

Thank you for providing those details. Based on the information you've given me, I suggest the following study arm design:

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: Subject glucometer measurement
   - Participant Group/Arm: Male or female patients with hypo-, eu- or hyperglycemia who have signed the written informed consent and are older than 18 years.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Diagnostic test using different blood glucose monitoring systems (BGM) and a reference method to measure blood glucose concentration. This arm is necessary to evaluate the system accuracy of the 14 blood glucose monitoring systems in comparison to a reference method. By including patients with different blood glucose levels, we can assess the performance of the systems across a range of glucose concentrations.

2. Control: Reference method measurement
   - Participant Group/Arm: Same participants as the Experimental arm.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Diagnostic test using a reference method to measure blood glucose concentration. This arm is necessary to establish a baseline for comparison with the results obtained from the different blood glucose monitoring systems. By using a standardized reference method, we can ensure consistency and accuracy in the evaluation of the system accuracy of the 14 blood glucose monitoring systems.

That's a valid point. Having a separate group of participants for the control arm would indeed be ideal to eliminate any potential bias. However, in this particular study, we are focusing on evaluating the system accuracy of the blood glucose monitoring systems within the same group of participants. This allows us to directly compare the performance of the systems in real-world conditions. If we were to use a separate group for the control arm, there could be variations in individual physiology and glucose levels that would introduce confounding factors. By using the same participants, we can minimize these variables and ensure a more accurate assessment of the system accuracy.

Note
There are several types of clinical trials that can be used to answer different types of research questions. For example, a randomized pilot trial would be used to test the feasibility and acceptability of an intervention. On the other hand, a randomized controlled trial is used to evaluate the efficacy of an intervention or treatment. A case-control study may be used to compare people with a disease (cases) to people without the disease (controls) and evaluate risk factors. A crossover study can investigate whether an intervention is more effective when given before or after another intervention.

For the hot compressing group, we expect warming the hands and feet before administration of Oxaliplatin to reduce the peripheral side effects of chemotherapy, such as nausea, vomiting, and neuropathy. As for the cold compressing group, we expect cooling the hands and feet before administration of Oxaliplatin to reduce systemic vasomotor symptoms such as shivering and shakes during chemotherapy. Additionally, we will look at psychological effects, such as anxiety, in both groups as a secondary outcome. Finally, we'll measure nausea, vomiting, and neuropathy rates within 24-hours of chemotherapy. For the cold compressing group, we'll measure these symptoms again at 72-hours to see if the effects of the intervention persist or resolve. For the control group, we expect no change in symptoms.

In the hot compressing group, temperature control will be maintained within the range of 37-38 degrees Celsius. This temperature is within a range that has been shown to be comfortable for many participants, and is also not extreme enough to cause burns or other physical harm. Hot compresses are commonly used as a treatment for a variety of conditions, including nerve pain and muscle spasms. Applying warmth to the affected limbs has been shown to reduce pain, numbness, and tingling, as well as improve grip strength and muscle control.

In the cold compressing group, patients will receive cool compresses on their hands and feet before and after Oxaliplatin administration. The temperature of the compresses will be kept within a range of 12-18 degrees Celsius. By using cold compresses, we aim to minimize peripheral neuropathy symptoms and improve the quality of life for those receiving chemotherapy. Adverse reactions will also be monitored to ensure safe use of the intervention.

For the purposes of the study, patients will be randomized to receive chemotherapy with oxaliplatin before or after hot or cold compression on the hands and feet. No intervention will be received by the control arm.

1. Why are there 3 different injection sites for QL1706H in the dose escalation study arm? The 3 different injection sites are aimed at optimizing QL1706H absorption. 2. Why do you choose every 21 days for the administration of QL1706H in the dose escalation study arm? Is every-other-week administration preferred for this type of drug? This is the commonly used administration interval for medications with the similar mechanism of action, which leads to the assumption that a similar efficacy and safety profile can be expected. 3. Why QL1706H will be administered by subcutaneous injection in the dose escalation study arm, but by IV infusion in the dose exploration study arm? In the dose escalation study, subcutaneous administration is tried to evaluate the possibility of minimizing side effects, such as anti-drug antibodies, for QL1706H. IV is typically used for drugs that function by direct targeting to their site of action. 4. How are the treatment and evaluation phases of this clinical trial designed? In the first 21 days of treatment, the dose and schedule will be evaluated. In the following 42 days, treatment will be administered according to the pre-established schedule.
5. Does the dose-escalation study continue until a particular dose of QL1706H is administered without DLTs or until a particular response rate is achieved? This study will continue until 3 cohorts have reached their highest tolerated dose without any DLTs. If no responses are observed at the highest tolerated dose, the next one will be investigated in another approach. 6. How is the patient population chosen for the dose-escalation study? This study will involve participants with advanced solid tumors with available disease sites where QL1706H can be administrated.

The Experimental: QL1706H Part 2 (Dose Exploration) arm is designed to evaluate the activity and safety of QL1706H in the treatment of advanced solid tumors. The PK study will evaluate what dose and dosing interval of QL1706H should be used in future studies based on the results of Part 1, by assessing the pharmacokinetics of QL1706H. This allows us to develop the proper dosing for QL1706H across potential treatment settings and routes.

Yes, of course. The study protocol for the QL1706H clinical trial includes three parts, which are as follows:
Part 1: Dose escalation in patients with advanced solid tumors
Part 2: Dose confirmation in patients with advanced solid tumors
Part 3: Dose expansion in patients with platinum-resistant recurrent ovarian cancer and advanced refractory serous ovarian and fallopian tube cancer
Study designs vary slightly between these parts due to different objectives. In Part 1, the target population is patients with advanced solid tumors, and the aim is to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of QL1706H. Dose escalation will occur in sequential cohorts of 3-6 patients and will stop when all cohorts have reached the highest tolerated dose or other predefined criteria. The dose escalation will be conducted in 28-day treatment cycles and patients will be monitored for 30 days after the last dose of QL1706H. In Part 2, the target population is patients with advanced solid tumors and the aim is to confirm the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of QL1706H at the optimal dose identified in part 1. Dose confirmation will occur in sequential cohorts of 3-6 patients and will stop when all cohorts have reached the optimal dose or other predefined criteria. The dose confirmation will have a 28-day treatment period and all patients will be followed up for 42 days after the last dose of QL1706H. In Part 3, the target population is patients with platinum-resistant recurrent ovarian cancer and advanced refractory serous ovarian and fallopian tube cancer, and the aim is to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and antitumor activity of QL1706H. Cohorts of 3-6 patients will be enrolled and dose escalation will stop when all patients have reached the highest tolerated dose or other criteria. The treatment duration will be 28 days and all patients will be followed up

Experimental: QL1706H Part 1 (Dose escalation): QL1706H will be administered in sequential cohorts, each receiving 1 dose of QL1706H by subcutaneous injection on day 1 and QL1706 by IV infusion on day 22. From then on, they will receive QL1706 on day 1 of every 21-day cycle. Dose escalation will continue until the projected cohorts have been finished.
2. Experimental: QL1706H Part 2 (Dose Exploration): The PK parameters of QL1706H will be tested at different administration intervals.

Absolutely! Let's start with the first study arm. The Experimental: QL1706H Part 1 (Dose escalation) arm is designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of QL1706H in patients with advanced solid tumors. By administering QL1706H in sequential cohorts with escalating doses, we aim to determine the maximum tolerated dose and the recommended dose for further studies. The subcutaneous injection on day 1 followed by IV infusion on day 22 allows for the assessment of different routes of administration and dosing schedules. This arm is necessary to establish the safety profile and optimal dosing regimen of QL1706H.

The Experimental: QL1706H Part 2 (Dose Exploration) arm focuses on exploring the pharmacokinetic parameters of QL1706H at different administration intervals. By testing the drug at various time points, we aim to understand its exposure levels, distribution, metabolism, and elimination in the body. This arm is essential for optimizing the dosing schedule and frequency of QL1706H to achieve the desired therapeutic effect while minimizing potential side effects. It will provide valuable information for future studies and clinical use of QL1706H.

Open-Label study: The study does not have disclosure of the study drugs at randomization. Sometimes drugs are not fully masked at randomization if it is a parallel-group study or if the groups are extremely small and the researchers feel that guessing the group assignment may not be possible.
Crossover study: A type of study where a single subject receives different treatments in a staggered manner or a subject switches between different treatments. ⏎
Stepped-wedge study: The study is neither a parallel-group study or a crossover study where one group receives the treatment first and the other receives it last while the order of groups is randomized. Instead, everything receives the treatment
For this type of design, you may also want to consider a placebo or comparison group arm to test the intervention's efficacy. Additionally, do you have any recommendations for read-out measures?

The control group is essential to demonstrate the intervention's effectiveness. It can help to determine whether the results are unique to the treatment or if they're due to the natural course of the disease. However, it can also be challenging to recruit participants for the control group. Additionally, there's also the possibility of contamination between the two groups. What do you suggest?

The control group should have similar characteristics to the intervention group, and the criteria should be clear and measurable. A reasonable inclusion criteria may be that individuals have mental health challenges but are not experiencing behavioral problems. Do you have any other design considerations?
Great, let's move on to the third arm.

This personalized approach aims to reduce behavioral problems and burden on healthcare providers.

Certainly! Here are the full study arms we have designed based on our discussion:

1. Experimental: Domiciliary CGA
   - Participant Group/Arm: Frail older adults over age 75 who are discharged from the Emergency Department and referred to the Community Specialist Team in Limerick.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The intervention will consist of domiciliary Comprehensive Geriatric Assessment (CGA) including nursing, medical, and allied health assessment and intervention. The majority of this intervention will be delivered in the patient's own home, with a medical review at the hub for specialist geriatric medical expertise. A domiciliary visit within 24-48 hours of referral will be conducted by a team member who will act as the case coordinator. Referrals for domiciliary care will be made based on patient needs, with individualized interventions prescribed. This arm aims to assess the impact of providing CGA in a home-based setting, which may improve patient comfort, accessibility, and overall outcomes.

2. Active Comparator: Hub-based CGA
   - Participant Group/Arm: Frail older adults over age 75 who are discharged from the Emergency Department and referred to the Community Specialist Team in Limerick.
   - Intervention/Treatment: CGA as defined above will be delivered in an Out-patient setting at the hub. This arm serves as the comparison group to the experimental arm, allowing for the evaluation of the effectiveness of domiciliary CGA compared to hub-based CGA. It is necessary to have this arm to assess whether the setting of CGA delivery impacts clinical and process outcomes among older adults.

groundtruth: For the active comparator arm, I suggest the participant group/arm: "Femoral Triangle Block (FTB) + IPACK block." This arm includes patients who will receive the standard treatment of FTB along with the IPACK block, which is considered the standard of care. The FTB is a commonly used nerve block for knee replacement surgery, but it does not fully cover the skin component of the surgical incision. By adding the IPACK block, the sensory branches of the innervation posterior to the knee are blocked. This arm serves as the control group to compare the efficacy of the experimental PACS block in improving postoperative analgesia.

Certainly! Here are the detailed interventions/treatments for each study arm:

1. Experimental: Para-Sartorial Compartment (PACS) Block + Femoral Triangle Block (FTB) + IPACK block
- Procedure: Para-Sartorial Compartments (PACS) Block
  - This intervention was selected because it has the potential to optimize analgesia by skin coverage of the upper third of the surgical incision. The intervention will be performed as follows:
    - The intermediate femoral cutaneous nerve will be visualized at the supralateral level of the sartorius muscle, in a duplicature of the fascia lata.
    - The needle will be inserted at the same puncture site as for the femoral triangle block, with a latero-medial orientation in the plane (intracanalar compartment).
    - In addition to the injection performed in the femoral triangle, two injections of 5 mL of 0.5% ropivacaine + epi 1:400 000 will be performed in addition, below the sartorius muscle (subsartorial compartment) and above the sartorius muscle (suprasartorial compartment).
- Procedure: Femoral Triangle Block (FTB)
  - The high frequency linear ultrasound probe will be positioned midway between the superior edge of the patella and the anterosuperior iliac spine. It will then be moved to visualize the apex of the femoral triangle, confirmed by visualization of the sartorius muscle laterally and the long adductor medially.
  - The needle will be inserted with a latero-medial orientation in the plane.
  - The initial injection will be a single injection of 15 ml of 0.5% ropivacaine + epi 1:400 000 under the sartorius muscle, lateral to the femoral artery, at the level of the apex of the femoral triangle.
- Procedure: Infiltration between popliteal artery and capsule of the knee (IPACK) block
  - It will be performed in order to block the sensory branches of the innervation posterior to the knee with 15 ml of ropivacaine 0.3% + epi 1:400 000.

2. Active Comparator: Femoral Triangle Block (FTB) + IPACK block
- Procedure: Femoral Triangle Block (FTB)
  - The high frequency linear ultrasound probe will be positioned midway between the superior edge of the patella and the anterosuperior iliac spine. It will then be moved to visualize the apex of the femoral triangle, confirmed by visualization of the sartorius muscle laterally and the long adductor medially.
  - The needle will be inserted with a latero-medial orientation in the plane.
  - The initial injection will be a single injection of 15 ml of 0.5% ropivacaine + epi 1:400 000 under the sartorius muscle, lateral to the femoral artery, at the level of the apex of the femoral triangle.
- Procedure: Infiltration between popliteal artery and capsule of the knee (IPACK) block
  - It will be performed in order to block the sensory branches of the innervation posterior to the knee with 15 ml of ropivacaine 0.3% + epi 1:400 000.

groundtruth:
Certainly! In Treatment plan I (PSCA CAR T-cells), patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer would undergo leukapheresis to collect their T cells. These T cells would then be modified in the laboratory to express the PSCA-specific CAR receptor. The modified T cells, known as PSCA-CAR T cells, would be infused into the patients intravenously up to 3 times during the study. Additionally, patients would undergo lymphodepletion therapy, bone scans, CT scans, tumor biopsies, and collection of blood, stool, and urine samples.

In Treatment plan II (PSCA CAR T-cells, radiation), patients would undergo the same interventions as in Treatment plan I, but with the addition of external beam radiation therapy. The radiation therapy would be administered in 2 doses and is intended to further target and destroy cancer cells. The rest of the procedures, including leukapheresis, lymphodepletion, imaging studies, and sample collection, would be the same as in Treatment plan I.

The MEA device is a non-rebreather mask with an in-built Hepat-Flow valve and an additional airway balloon located before the Hepat-Flow valve. By inflating the balloon the resistance to airway can be increased to reduce the O2 requirements for a given flow of gas to the patient. The primary outcome is the time till a clinician has to increase the FiO2 to maintain an O2 saturation of 90% in the desaturating patients. A number of non-invasive techniques have been evaluated and shown that increasing the resistance of the breathing circuit reduces the FiO2 requirements during invasive TEE. The reduction in FiO2 is proportional to the resistance to airway. The safety concern regarding the HEPA filter of the MEA has been evaluated and deemed acceptable based on prior experiences with bronchoscopic procedures. The control arm is a nasal cannula as is in routine use for airway oxygenation during TEE.

Certainly! In the Experimental: Active tDCS arm, participants will undergo five in-person visits in Week 1 for the administration of active transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS). From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly active tDCS sessions preceding the scheduled yoga sessions. The tDCS sessions will involve the administration of a constant anodal current of 2 mA for 20 minutes, targeting the primary motor cortex contralateral to the most painful site. The yoga program will be led by a certified instructor and will consist of centring, warming up, yoga postures, and guided relaxation.

In the Sham Comparator: Sham tDCS arm, participants will attend five in-person visits in Week 1 for the administration of sham transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS). From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly sham tDCS sessions before the scheduled yoga sessions. The sham tDCS sessions will mimic the sensation of current without actual stimulation. Participants will also participate in the same yoga program led by a certified instructor.

model_response: The primary design for the IA arm will be an ABA crossover design, in which participants will receive the intervention followed by a wait period, then the control intervention, and finally a wait period before the next intervention. This allows for an evaluation of the immediate impact of the intervention, its longer-term maintenance, and how it compares to the control condition. Participants will complete a daily self-report survey to evaluate their well-being throughout the intervention and wait periods.

The intervention for the IA + SSC Condition will be slightly altered. Participants will follow the same prompts as the IA Condition, but instead of writing about their own experience, they will be asked to write to someone they consider a supportive confidant, such as a parent, sibling, friend, or counselor. They will then be asked to write a letter of gratitude to this individual describing their support and expressing appreciation. The writing period on this letter will be shorter than the vignette, with a maximum of two writing periods over four days.

In the Control Condition, participants will complete the same prompts as the other two arms but will not be provided with any specific intervention content; instead, they will be asked to complete the writing exercise about their day without any prompts or questions about internalized transphobia or gratitude. This arm serves as a control to evaluate whether the changes observed in the other two conditions are due to specific prompts or writing activities, versus other factors like mood and reflective thinking.  For example, some writing exercises have been shown to reduce symptoms of anxiety and depression by increasing positive automatic thoughts and emotions (Pennebaker & Beane, 2007); it is possible that some of the observed outcomes could be due to these effects, rather than the specific prompts provided.
groundtruth: For the TNB Identity Affirmation (IA) Condition, participants will receive the same prompt for all four days of writing. This design, often used in expressive writing interventions, allows for deeper and continued reflection into specific thoughts and emotions. The prompt will involve reading a vignette that describes the experience and response of a young adult who experiences rejection from a close friend after a first disclosure of their gender identity. Participants will then be asked to write in response to three prompts: 1) identify expressions of internalized transphobia in the vignette character, 2) reflect on times the participant has experienced similar feelings, 3) identify thoughts and feelings that promote and support a positive and affirming identity in contrast to negative emotions and thoughts.

In the IA + Strengthening Social Connections (SSC) Condition, participants will complete the TNB Identity Affirmation intervention on the first three days, following the same prompts as the previous arm. On the fourth day, participants will be directed to compose a brief letter of gratitude to an individual to whom they have not previously expressed gratitude, and who has provided meaningful and affirming support to them as a TNB person. This additional component aims to further enhance social connections and gratitude, which are important factors in promoting well-being.

In the Control Condition, participants will engage in expressive writing about events of the day, without any specific prompts related to TNB identity or social connections. This neutral writing task will serve as a comparison to evaluate the specific impact of the TNB Identity Affirmation and Social Connection interventions on reducing internalized stigma and promoting well-being, compared to general expressive writing.

Exactly! You have successfully designed the study arms. These arms will allow us to assess the impact of TNB Identity Affirmation and Social Connection interventions on reducing stigma and promoting well-being in TNB individuals. Well done!

Cycling on static exercise bikes at a standardized intensity allows for controlled exposure to different air quality environments, providing valuable data on the respiratory responses to varying levels of non-tailpipe emissions. This study arm is essential for achieving the goals of the study and obtaining meaningful results on the respiratory impacts of non-tailpipe emissions on adults with asthma.

Sham Treatment - This arm would involve delivering non-active mock interventions that resemble the active treatment but with no true active intervention. 4. Participant Blinded - In this study arm, participants would be blinded to their group assignment throughout the study. Clinician and participant blinding could be maintained or not maintained. 6. - Ziv-Aflibercept is an investigational or experimental anti-cancer agent that inactivates vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) from functioning. It has been shown to prevent the formation of new blood vessels in tumors and inhibit tumor growth. Blocking VEGF may also enhance the immune response against cancer.
- Cemiplimab is a human monoclonal anti-PD-1 antibody that works by blocking the programmed death-1 (PD-1) receptor on immune cells. This helps enhance the immune response against cancer cells.

groundtruth: In Phase 1 dose expansion cohorts, patients with Microsatellite Stable (MSS) CRC can have no more than 3 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease. For H&N cancer, they can have no more than 2 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease. For melanoma, they can have no more than 3 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, including at least 1 prior treatment with a BRAF inhibitor for patients with a BRAF mutation. For NSCLC, they can have no more than 2 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, including at least 1 prior treatment with a targeted therapy for patients with a mutation such as EGFR, ALK, KRAS, or RET. It's important to consider these criteria when enrolling patients in the dose expansion cohorts.

It's important to keep blinding to the treatment as much as possible, so we could consider using a crossover design to switch the groups at midpoint, so that those in the control arm receive myofunctional therapy and vice versa. - Participant Group/Arm: This group will receive both picture-based prevention education and participate in an educational course.

By combining both visual aids and a structured course, participants are more likely to retain and apply the information provided, leading to potentially better outcomes in terms of reducing the incidence and severity of hand eczema.

2. Experimental: Group 2: Picture-based prevention education only (no educational course)
- Participant Group/Arm: This group will only receive picture-based prevention education without participating in an educational course.
- Intervention/Treatment: The participants will have access to visual aids for understanding and preventing hand eczema but will not receive the additional training provided in the educational course.
- Reasoning: This study arm is necessary to evaluate the effectiveness of picture-based prevention education alone in preventing hand eczema. By isolating this intervention, researchers can determine its impact on the outcomes compared to the group that receives both visual education and a course. This arm helps to assess the specific contribution of visual aids in preventing hand eczema among hospital cleaners.

3. Placebo Comparator: Group 3: Placebo (control)
- Participant Group/Arm: This group will serve as the control group and will not receive any picture-based prevention education or educational course.
- Intervention/Treatment: The participants in this group will not have access to the interventions provided to the experimental groups.

This arm helps to control for any external factors that may influence the outcomes and allows for a more accurate assessment of the interventions' effectiveness.

Certainly! The participant group/arm for the experimental arm will be named "Early Initiated Physiotherapy Intervention." This arm will involve all participants receiving the intervention, which is physical activity. The intervention will primarily focus on exercises that can improve venous return and will consist of progressive walking training at moderate and high intensity. Participants will also receive guidance on physical activity. The training program is inspired by the WHO's recommendations for physical activity. Initially, there will be a 14-day introductory period where the goal is to achieve 30 minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity per day. After 14 days, the patient will receive physiotherapeutic guidance in physical activity and progress to the next period of 14 days, aiming for 2 sessions of 20 minutes of high-intensity physical activity per week. After one month of training, the patient will be guided on maintaining and possibly progressing physical activity. This arm will help us assess the value of early-initiated physiotherapy in improving outcomes for DVT patients.

Examples of Clinical Study Designs Using the Interventions "Sham Treatment" vs. "Active (or Real) Treatment" (intervention vs. control)
There are many different types of study designs that we can use to investigate the efficacy of a new medical device or treatment. One of the most common is the randomized double-blind placebo-controlled study. This study design involves two arms, an intervention arm (treatment) and a control arm (sham or sham treatment). The intervention arm receives the actual treatment while the control arm receives the "sham treatment". The "sham" treatment typically looks and feels like the real treatment but does not use the actual treatment under investigation. The goal is to ensure that the intervention and the control arm are as similar as possible so that any changes observed can be attributed to the real treatment.
Another popular study design is the placebo-controlled cross-over study. In a placebo-controlled cross-over study, all subjects are first assigned to the placebo and then to the active treatment to get a more direct comparison of the two. Here is an example of a cross-over study protocol for a pain management device (intervention) vs. placebo:
Protocol: A double-blind placebo-controlled crossover study of pain and symptoms associated with knee OA.
Active Treatment Intervention: A new knee pain management device is used on the affected knee.
Control Arm 1: Sham treatment to the sham knee
Control Arm 2: Sham treatment to the affected knee and the actual treatment is applied to the sham knee.

Root canal therapy is a common treatment option in cases of irreversible pulpitis in mature molars. However, it can be associated with a high incidence of failures due to complexRoot canal anatomy, reinfection and other factors. Thus, total pulpotomy has been shown to be a promising treatment option in cases where the pulp is necrotic or irreversibly inflamed and can't be saved. In total pulpotomy, the coronal pulp tissue is removed and the remaining pulp is regenerated, which will give rise to a non-vital tooth.
Sure, let's proceed with the design of the study arms.
groundtruth:
Certainly! The experimental arm of total pulpotomy is necessary to assess the efficacy of this treatment option in managing post-operative pain in mature molars with severe irreversible pulpitis. By comparing the outcomes with the root canal treatment arm, the study aims to provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of total pulpotomy in such cases.

The active comparator arm of root canal treatment serves as the standard comparison for total pulpotomy. Root canal treatment is the conventional method for managing irreversible pulpitis, and comparing it with total pulpotomy will help determine the most effective treatment option for such cases. By evaluating post-operative pain outcomes in this arm, the study can provide evidence-based recommendations for clinicians.

Great! Here are the full study arms:

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: Total pulpotomy
   - Participant Group/Arm: Individuals with severe symptoms indicative of irreversible pulpitis in mature molar teeth.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Complete removal of the coronal pulp tissue, achieving hemostasis with 2.5% sodium hypochlorite, placement of a 3 mm thick MTA material in the pulp chamber, closure of the pulp chamber with glass ionomer cement, and restoration with composite filling.

2. Active Comparator: Root canal treatment
   - Participant Group/Arm: Individuals with severe symptoms indicative of irreversible pulpitis in mature molar teeth.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Determining the working length, chemomechanical preparation using specific files, irrigation with NaOCl and EDTA, and filling the root canals with epoxy-resin-based sealer using lateral condensation technique.

The study design for the study under discussion will involve assessment of the impact of implementing innovative diagnostic technologies in ICU patients with bacteremia. The study will have two arms, one before the intervention and the other after introducing these technologies. Arm 1 (before intervention) will include evaluation of bacteremia episodes using routine blood culture techniques, such as, the reference method. The assessment will be done in terms of duration of time to detect bacteremia, positivity rate, resistance trends, and changes in duration and intensity of antimicrobial use.

   - Target Population: All adult hospitalized patients in ICU with Gram-negative bacteremia between November 1, 2020 and January 15, 2021.

   - Sample Size/Statistical Considerations: Determined in consultation with statisticians. 
   - Exclusion Criteria:  
- Patients who don't agree to participate or are unable to give informed consent.
- Patients who have undergone previous antibiotic treatment or received prior blood transfusion during their hospitalization.

- Hospitalization records, data regarding comorbidities, demographics and medical history.

The COMET initiative
There are several key aspects to consider when designing a randomized clinical trial in urologic medicine. One set of criteria that has been used for many years is the "Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials (CONSORT) Extension Statement". These include items aimed at improving the reporting of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) with a particular focus on clinical trials of medicinal products.
The CONSORT Extension Statement aims to improve reporting of the design, conduct, and reporting of RCTs of nonpharmacological, noninterventions trials, such as surgical trials. Recently, an extension of the original statement was released to help ensure rigor and transparency in the reporting of studies of measurement and diagnostic accuracy, the so-called "The CONSORT ESA."
Another similar initiative is the "The Recommendations for Reporting Urological Protective Equipment (RReME) checklist" which "provides a framework for authors to report the design and conduct of urological protective equipment trials, including single centre studies and multi-center studies, randomized trials, observational studies and non-comparative studies, in the form of a pre-registration form, as a checklist, or in the form of a structured abstract.
An extension to the RReME consensus statement was developed at the 2nd International MEta-Analysis Of Urologic PROtective Equipment (META-UROPE) Workshop. [2] This new statement aims to provide guidance for the reporting of urological protective equipment trials (i.e., non-pharmacological interventions), as well as studies of measurement and diagnostic accuracy, of which urological protective equipment is an integral part.

The goal of this design is to test the hypothesis that Ghrelin will improve patient outcomes in ischemic stroke. Ghrelin has already been shown to have neuroprotective effects in animal models of stroke. Based on that, we believe it may improve outcomes in patients with ischemic stroke. [IN SUP] The control group/arm will receive standard care and treatment, apart from thrombolysis.
The control group will receive the standard of care, which will include early endovascular thrombectomy, based on ESC guidelines.
The intervention/treatment for the control group will be no intervention, no acylated Ghrelin administration. This group will receive only the standard care.

The control group design allows us to compare the effects of Ghrelin treatment to the effects of standard care, and to determine whether the treatment is efficacious. Without this comparison, we cannot know whether the effects we observe are specific to the treatment or to other interventions that were not received.

The experimental (or intervention) arm of the study will be "Experimental: Ghrelin," which will receive 600mcg of Ghrelin dissolved in 50cc normal saline, administered intravenously for 5 consecutive days after stroke onset. The control (or comparison) arm will be "Control", which is for comparative purposes only, and will receive normal saline infusion. Patients will be followed up at one month and one year post randomization for the primary outcome measure of functional independence, defined as the modified Rankin Score. The safety measures which will be measured during the trial are - Change in blood pressure(systolic/diastolic) - Change in respiratory rate - Change in body temperature - Vital signs:- change in heart rate.
groundtruth: The intervention/treatment for the experimental arm will be the administration of 600mcg of Ghrelin dissolved in 50cc normal saline. This will be administered by bolus infusion twice daily for five days, in addition to the standard treatment, including intravenous thrombolysis if indicated.

The experimental arm is designed to test the hypothesis that Ghrelin can improve early recovery and long-term functional outcomes in stroke patients undergoing endovascular thrombectomy (EVT). By administering Ghrelin in the first six hours after stroke onset, we aim to assess its potential neuroprotective and neurorestorative effects in this population.

The participant group/arm for the control group will be labeled as "No Intervention: Standard care". This group will consist of patients who will receive standard care for stroke, including intravenous thrombolysis if indicated.

The control group will not receive Ghrelin treatment. Instead, they will be managed according to local practices for the treatment of stroke, including standard care and intravenous thrombolysis if indicated.

The control group serves as a comparison to assess the specific effects of Ghrelin on stroke recovery and functional outcomes. By including a control group, we can evaluate the impact of Ghrelin without confounding factors from other interventions, providing a clearer understanding of its potential benefits.

   - Intervention/Treatment: Patients will not receive Ghrelin treatment but will be managed according to local practices for stroke treatment.

This will help validate the results obtained from the experimental arm.

1. Active Comparator: Oral steroid
Participant Group/Arm: Patients given prednisone 1 mg/kg for 3 days then tapered by 5mg daily for two weeks
Intervention/Treatment: Drug: Prednisone
Reasoning: This arm serves as the active comparator to compare the efficacy of budesonide intrapolyp injection to the standard treatment of oral steroids in managing type 2 chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps. Prednisone is a commonly used systemic steroid in the treatment of chronic rhinosinusitis, so including this arm allows for a comparison of the effectiveness of budesonide intrapolyp injection.

2. Experimental: Budesonide Intrapolyp injection
Participant Group/Arm: Patients given budesonide 0.5 mg/2ml intrapolyp injection once weekly for 5 consecutive weeks
Intervention/Treatment: Drug: Budesonide
Reasoning: This arm is the experimental group that receives the intervention being studied in this trial. Budesonide is being investigated as a potential treatment option for type 2 chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps. By administering budesonide intrapolyp injection, the researchers aim to evaluate its efficacy in reducing symptoms and improving outcomes in comparison to the standard treatment of oral steroids.

3. Placebo Comparator: Saline intrapolyp injection
Participant Group/Arm: Patients given 2ml normal saline intrapolyp injection once weekly for 5 consecutive weeks
Intervention/Treatment: Drug: Saline
Reasoning: The placebo comparator arm is essential to assess the specific effects of budesonide intrapolyp injection compared to a placebo. By administering saline intrapolyp injections, researchers can control for the placebo effect and evaluate the true impact of budesonide on the management of type 2 chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps. This arm helps ensure the validity and reliability of the study results.

1. Experimental: Pneumatic Compression Therapy (PCT)
- Participant Group/Arm: This arm consists of participants who will receive Pneumatic Compression Therapy (PCT) as the intervention.
- Intervention/Treatment:
  - Drug: Indocyanine green (ICG) dye: The use of ICG dye allows for visualization of lymphatic drainage pathways and assessment of lymphatic function.
  - Device: NIRF-LI imaging: Near-infrared fluorescence lymphatic imaging will be used to assess the drainage of ICG-laden lymph from injection sites towards regional nodal basins.
  - Device: Neuroglide pad: Participants will lie on the Neuroglide pad for the one-hour PCT treatment session.
- Reasoning: This arm is necessary to evaluate the effectiveness of Pneumatic Compression Therapy (PCT) in improving lymphatic function. The combination of ICG dye for visualization, NIRF-LI imaging for assessment, and the Neuroglide pad for treatment allows for a comprehensive evaluation of lymphatic response to the therapy.

2. No Intervention: Control Group
- Participant Group/Arm: This arm consists of participants who will not receive any specific intervention.
- Intervention/Treatment: None
- Reasoning: The inclusion of a control group is essential to compare the outcomes of the experimental arm receiving PCT with those of participants not undergoing any intervention.
