Certainly! The intervention in the experimental arm will involve participants using the ISO-101 device. This is a wearable wrist device that aims to improve orthostatic hypotension by minimizing the postural change in blood pressure. This trial will take place at a single center and participants will be recruited from the outpatient hypertension clinic. Eligible participants include those with a clinically diagnosed orthostatic hypotension, as detected by a drop in systolic blood pressure of ≥20 mmHg within 3 minutes of standing up, as well as those with a resting diastolic blood pressure ≤50 mmHg. Participants will be excluded if they have a prior history of syncope, a recent history of heart attack, renal disease, a pacemaker, pregnant or breastfeeding women, or any other contraindications for isosceles, such as severe claustrophobia, depression, or fever at the time of assessment. Participants in both arms will be instructed to maintain their usual antihypertensive medications throughout the trial. During the study, the participants will be asked to wear the device for 14 days. On visit 1, the participants will undergo a 10-minute battery of tests, which will include measurements of vital signs, calibration of the isosceles, and then a tilt test, where the participant will stay still for five minutes, then stand up and their blood pressure and heart rate will be recorded over the next 10 minutes. They will get to wear the blood pressure monitor for another 3~ days and keep a diary of each 30-minute period where they get up from a sitting or lying down position to stand. On their final visit, which will be at day 14, they will have another round of the above tests and they will take home the isosceles and will be asked to return it by mail. Participants will be asked not to modify their physical activity or medication intake during the trial. They will also be asked to complete the Symptomatic Orthostatic Hypotension Quality of Life Questionnaire, the Short form of the EQ-5D Health Status Questionnaire, the Short Physical General Health Scale and the Nottingham Facial Cognitive Impair

The No Intervention: Control arm is important to compare the effects of the ISO-101 device. By comparing the results of the Control and Experimental arms, we can more effectively evaluate the role of the ISO-101 device in treating orthostatic hypotension.

In the experimental arm, patients will receive Wilate® at a dose of 30-60 IU VWF:RCo/kg for the two anticipated heaviest days of bleeding every 24-48 hours within the first 4 days of menstruation, with the option for additional doses if needed. This arm aims to evaluate the efficacy of prophylactic Wilate® in reducing heavy menstrual bleeding in patients with VWD. The dosing schedule is designed to mimic real-world use and provide optimal benefit to patients.

In the placebo comparator arm, patients will receive intravenous placebo (normal saline) at the same approximate volume and frequency as the study drug. This arm is crucial in determining the true efficacy of the pdVWF:FVIII concentrate (Wilate®) compared to no treatment. By comparing outcomes between the experimental arm and the placebo arm, researchers can assess the specific impact of the active treatment on heavy menstrual bleeding in patients with VWD. Additionally, the placebo arm helps ensure blinding and reduces bias in the study results.

This intervention aims to improve depressive symptoms in LLD patients who have not responded to traditional antidepressant therapy.
   - Reasoning: This arm is necessary to assess the efficacy of tDCS as an adjunctive treatment for LLD. By comparing the outcomes of participants receiving active tDCS to those receiving sham tDCS, we can determine the true effects of tDCS on depressive symptoms in this population.

2. Sham Comparator: Sham tDCS
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes participants who will receive sham Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Participants in this arm will undergo a sham tDCS procedure, where the electrode positions and stimulation parameters are the same as active tDCS, but the current is only delivered for the initial 30 seconds.
   - Reasoning: The inclusion of a sham comparator arm is essential to control for placebo effects and ensure the validity of the study results. By comparing the outcomes of participants receiving sham tDCS to those receiving active tDCS, we can determine if any observed effects are due to the actual stimulation or simply the placebo effect. This arm helps to establish the true efficacy of tDCS in treating LLD.

- Participant Group/Arm: The patients in the experimental group will be given a stress ball before the subcutaneous injection during the routine daytime treatment of the ward at 10:00. In the meantime, 0.4 ml of LMWH will be administered by subcutaneous route according to the doctor's request. The level of pain in the area where the subcutaneous injection was applied will be evaluated with the Visual Analog Scale (VAS).
- Intervention/Treatment: Stress ball use during subcutaneous injection.
- Purpose: To investigate the effect of stress ball use on pain during subcutaneous injection.

- Participant Group/Arm: The patients in the control group will not receive any intervention before the subcutaneous injection. They will receive 0.4 ml of LMWH administered by the nurse in the routine daytime treatment of the service at 10:00, according to the doctor's request. The level of pain in the area where the subcutaneous injection was applied will be evaluated with the VAS.

This means that participants will be randomized to receive either NVP-2203 or NVP-2203-R in one period and then switch to the other treatment in a subsequent period. By using a crossover design, researchers can minimize the potential influence of confounding factors and compare the effects of the two treatments within the same participants.

Absolutely! In the experimental RECTUS group, after induction of general anesthesia, an ultrasound-guided Parasternal Block will be performed with 20 mL of ropivacaine 0.5% per side. At the end of surgery, a rectus sheath block will be performed with 10 mL of ropivacaine 0.25% per side. The active comparator CONTROL group will undergo the same procedures as the experimental group, except that instead of rectus sheath block, a local infiltration of drainage exit sites will be performed with 10 mL of ropivacaine 0.25% per side at the end of surgery. These interventions will allow us to evaluate the effectiveness of combining both parasternal block and rectus sheath block in providing preoperative analgesia and reducing opioid consumption.

groundtruth: Thank you for the detailed criteria. Now, let's discuss the design of each study arm. We have two arms: the experimental arm and the active comparator arm. Let's start with the experimental arm. In this arm, we will combine physical stress (ergometry) and pharmacological stress for perfusion assessment. The intervention will involve a combined stress test using a bicycle ergometry and pharmacological stress with Regadenoson. We will also measure high-sensitive Troponin levels before and after the stress test. This arm aims to improve the diagnostic accuracy of CMR stress testing by adding exercise testing and biomarker measurement. It will be particularly beneficial for patients with balanced ischemia or severe CAD. What do you think?

I'm glad you agree. Now, let's move on to the active comparator arm. In this arm, patients will undergo only pharmacological stress testing using Regadenoson. High-sensitive Troponin levels will also be measured before and after the stress test. This arm will serve as the control group for comparison with the experimental arm. It will help us assess the added value of incorporating physical stress (exercise) in the diagnostic protocol. What are your thoughts on this arm?

Excellent! Now that we have discussed and finalized the design of both study arms, here are the full study arms:

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: Combined stress test (pharmacological and physical stress)
   - Participant Group/Arm: Patients undergoing both physical stress (ergometry) and pharmacological stress for perfusion assessment.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Diagnostic Test: Exercise in combination with biomarkers and pharmacological stress CMR test. A bicycle ergometry combined with pharmacological stress test is performed. High-sensitive Troponin is taken before and after the stress test.

2. Active Comparator: Pharmacological stress test
   - Participant Group/Arm: Patients undergoing only pharmacological stress test with Regadenoson.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Diagnostic Test: Exercise in combination with biomarkers and pharmacological stress CMR test. A bicycle ergometry combined with pharmacological stress test is performed. High-sensitive Troponin is taken before and after the stress test.

For the Control Group, patients will not receive the Tripegfilgrastim injection and will only receive the standard of care treatment. Both groups will be followed up with regularly to monitor for any adverse effects.

In the Control Group, participants will not receive the Tripegfilgrastim intervention. The duration of treatment is the same for both groups. Patients in the Control Group will not receive Tripegfilgrastim, but they will continue to receive all other treatments as usual. The comparison of the safety and efficacy between the two arms will help us determine the impact of Tripegfilgrastim in the management of chemotherapy-induced severe neutropenia in patients with unresectable pancreaticobiliary cancers.

groundtruth: Certainly! Let's start with the Experimental Treatment Group. In this group, patients will receive a combination chemotherapy regimen consisting of Onivyde, Leucovorin, 5-FU, and Tripegfilgrastim. The chemotherapy will be administered every two weeks. Tripegfilgrastim will be administered 24 hours after completing the 5-FU infusion to reduce the risk of severe neutropenia. The inclusion of premedication and specific chemotherapy drugs is essential for the standardization of treatment across all participants in this arm. This arm is necessary to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Tripegfilgrastim in reducing the risk of severe neutropenia in patients with unresectable pancreaticobiliary cancers.

In the No Intervention Control Group, patients will receive the same combination chemotherapy regimen as the Experimental Treatment Group, but without the administration of Tripegfilgrastim. In the event of febrile neutropenia, Tripegfilgrastim will be administered after stopping 5-FU. Chemotherapy will be paused until the patient recovers from neutropenia, and then restarted after recovery. This arm is important to compare the outcomes of patients receiving standard chemotherapy without Tripegfilgrastim to those receiving Tripegfilgrastim in the treatment group. This will help determine the effectiveness of Tripegfilgrastim in reducing the risk of severe neutropenia in this patient population.

Writing the abstract should be the final step in protocol development. It should summarize the purpose of the study in a few concise sentences. The abstract will be listed in medical databases alongside study title and author information and needs to be engaging and impactful. It will also help prospective participants understand the key points of the study. Here's an example of a well-written study abstract:
This randomized controlled trial aims to evaluate the efficacy of extracorporeal photopheresis against placebo in the treatment of severe acute graft-versus-host-disease.
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of extracorporeal photopheresis in the treatment of severe acute graft-versus-host-disease.
Graft-versus-host-disease is a serious and sometimes life-threatening complication of bone marrow transplantation. Extracorporeal photopheresis is a novel treatment option that has been observed to be effective in small case series which may help to potentially improve symptoms and reduce mortality rate. This randomized controlled trial will help to clarify the efficacy of extracorporeal photopheresis compared to placebo in a larger patient population.
Study participants will be between 18-80 years of age with a confirmed diagnosis of severe acute graft-versus-host-disease. Study intervention will be extracorporeal photopheresis or placebo. The primary outcome measure will be change in health-related quality of life, as measured by standard questionnaires. Secondary outcomes will include improvement in symptoms, progression-free survival, and mortality rate at six months. This trial will take place in participating centers across the United States and will be completed in December 2022.
Explanation : This is an investigator-initiated randomized controlled trial to assess the effectiveness of extracorporeal photopheresis in severe acute graft-versus-host-disease. The purpose of the study is to improve the quality of life and potentially reduce mortality rate in patients with severe acute graft-versus-host-disease. The study population will include individuals of all ages with a confirmed diagnosis of severe acute graft-versus-host-dise

Thank you for the detailed criteria. Now let's move on to the design of the study arms. Based on the information you provided, I suggest the following study arms:

Study Arm 1:
Participant Group/Arm: Patients with stage II to IV (M0) CSCC who are candidates for surgery but have an increased risk of recurrence and/or risk of disfigurement or loss of function.
Intervention/Treatment: Cemiplimab 350 mg intravenously every 3 weeks for up to 12 weeks (up to 4 doses), or until unacceptable toxicity, disease progression, or withdrawal of consent.

Reasoning: This study arm is necessary to evaluate the efficacy and safety of cemiplimab in patients with CSCC who are at high risk of recurrence or disfigurement. The dosing schedule and duration are designed to assess the response to treatment over a defined period. This arm will provide valuable information on the potential benefits of cemiplimab in this specific patient population.

Study Arm 2:
Participant Group/Arm: Patients with stage II to IV (M0) CSCC who are candidates for surgery but have an increased risk of recurrence and/or risk of disfigurement or loss of function.
Intervention/Treatment: Cemiplimab 50 mg/mL supplied as a sterile liquid in single-use glass vials.

Reasoning: This study arm serves as a control or reference group to compare the outcomes of the patients receiving the higher dose of cemiplimab in Study Arm 1. By including a lower dose arm, researchers can assess the dose-response relationship and potential differences in efficacy and safety between the two doses. This arm is essential for evaluating the optimal dose of cemiplimab for the treatment of CSCC patients.

This summary is comprehensive and can be used as-is as the full study arms explanation in the trial. {{pillow}} ==Eligibility and exclusion criteria== Each participant should meet all of the following criteria in order to be enrolled in the study:  Must be at least 21 years old Must be a current smoker or have quit for at least 6 months Must have a cough or abnormal cough frequency or perceptions (as determined by a screening questionnaire) Must have tried at least 2 different smoking cessation methods, but are currently not using any form of nicotine replacement therapy Must provide written informed consent Must not have any medical condition that may interfere with completion of the study (as per discretion of the investigator/physician) Must not be pregnant or breast-feeding {{pillow}} ==Participation in the study== Participants will be recruited from outpatient clinics at the study site. groundtruth: Certainly! In the experimental arm, participants will have access to five treatment-specific videos ranging from 2-5 minutes in length. They are asked to watch these videos at least once weekly. The videos will discuss daily training exercises that should take no more than a few minutes to complete. Participants will also be asked to complete a progress check question each week to indicate their adherence to the program.

In the sham comparator arm, participants will also have access to five videos ranging from 2-5 minutes in length. Similar to the experimental arm, they are asked to watch these videos at least once weekly. The videos will discuss daily training exercises that should take no more than a few minutes to complete. Participants in this arm will also complete a progress check question each week to indicate their adherence to the program.

Including both the experimental and sham comparator arms is crucial for assessing the specific effects of the Internet-Behavioral Cough Suppression Therapy. By comparing the outcomes of participants receiving the experimental intervention to those receiving the sham treatment, researchers can determine whether any observed improvements are due to the active components of the therapy or simply to non-specific factors such as attention or expectation. This arm helps control for potential placebo effects and provides a more accurate assessment of the intervention's efficacy.

Random allocation is indeed a common and effective approach for ensuring unbiased distribution of participants. It helps minimize selection bias and ensures that any observed differences between the two arms are more likely to be attributable to the interventions themselves. This allocation method is suitable for this trial.

Yes, there is masking in place for this trial. It follows a single-blind design, where participants are unaware of which arm they have been assigned to. This helps minimize potential bias and ensures that participants' expectations do not influence their responses or behaviors.

The aim of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a novel combination of Dostarlimab, Bevacizumab, and Niraparib in platinum-resistant ovarian cancer. Primary ovarian cancer is the leading cause of death among gynecologic malignancies in the United States. Despite advances in diagnosis and treatment, 40% of women with ovarian cancer are diagnosed at a point of platinum resistance. We previously identified a combination of Dostarlimab, an anti- PD-1 checkpoint inhibitor, and Niraparib as a promising therapeutic combination in preclinical models of platinum resistant ovarian cancer. We are investigating this combination in a Phase 1b study.  In the proposed first cohort of the study, eligible participants will receive Dostarlimab at a dose of 10 mg/kg every 3 weeks in combination with Niraparib (3PARP, 200mg bid) for 21 days every 28 days. Participants will receive up to 5 doses of Dostarlimab/Niraparib every 28 days in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable side effects. The aim of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination of Dostarlimab, Bevacizumab, and Niraparib in participants with platinum resistant ovarian cancer.

The other arm of this trial will be the control arm, or placebo arm, with the following details: "Control: observation only - no treatment/intervention." Participants will receive no treatment/intervention other than standard care.

Maitland mobilization is a type of articular method, wherein the practitioner uses short lever arm muscle energy techniques and low-energy passive movements to help restore movement. The treatment is not painful or forceful. It's a low-load, low-intensity approach.

Interferential therapy works by delivering two electrical currents of different frequencies and intensities in alternating directions to the affected joint. The parameters that will be used in the study include frequency of 20Hz, intensity of 40mA, and a treatment duration of 20 minutes.

Mulligan's mobilization techniques include the following components: The practitioner will stand at the side of the patient, holding their hand behind the knee at the popliteal fossa at a 75-90-degree angle. The practitioner will apply pressure with their fingers and move their hand towards the front of the knee, following the leg and knee joint line. The practitioner will continue moving their hand away towards the lateral side of the knee until a click or 'pop' is achieved. This process will be repeated on the lateral side. The practitioner will apply pressure with his or her lateral fingers on the posterior fibers of the greater trochanters of both the femur and tibia. The practitioner will move their fingers towards the knee joint line, creating movement at the hip, knee, and ankle joints. The practitioner may then apply pressure with both hands over the posterior fibers of the gluteus maximus muscles, in a straight-leg-raise maneuver. The practitioner will turn out the hips and knees towards each other, in the patient's sagittal plane, using their hands to facilitate movement. The practitioner will stand behind the patient, with the patient's knee bent at around 30-45 degrees in a lunge position, and apply pressure over the posterior fibers of the greater trochanter of the femur and medial joints fibers of the tibia. They will then return the limb to the initial position. These procedures may be repeated on the other side of the limb.  The practitioner will follow the protocol outlined for the anterior fibers of the gluteus maximus muscle, and also for the inferior fibers of the rectus femoris and hamstrings muscles. These procedures are repeated for the patella. The practitioner and patient will stand in the initial position for the patella and repeat the same maneuvers for the inferior fibers of the rectus femoris muscles. Finally, the practitioner will repeat the same movements for the anterior fibers of the hamstring muscles. The practitioner will again repeat the patella maneuvers as outlines before.
The parameters for interferential therapy in the active comparator group are the same as for the experimental group.
The arms for the study are as follows: 1. Experimental arm: Maitland's technique with interferential therapy. 2. Active comparator arm: Mulligan's technique with interferential therapy.

Maitland's mobilization technique consists of several components, including distraction, anteroposterior glides, posteroanterior glides, medial glides, and lateral glides. These components will be performed on the patients in the experimental group.

The interferential therapy parameters for this study are as follows: carrier frequency 4000Hz, waveform rectangular, sweep time 1 second rise and fall and 5-second stay, treatment duration 10 minutes, and sweep frequency 10 to 130 Hz. The current intensity should be adjusted until the subject reports feeling a strong tingling sensation without causing muscle contraction. Additionally, an aquatic gel should be applied before strapping the electropads over the treatment area for smooth electrical conduction.

Certainly! Mulligan's mobilization technique includes medial mobilization with movement (MWM) for knee flexion and extension, as well as lateral mobilization with movement (MWM) for knee flexion and extension. These components will be performed on the patients in the active comparator group.

The interferential therapy parameters for the active comparator arm are the same as those in the experimental arm: carrier frequency 4000Hz, waveform rectangular, sweep time 1 second rise and fall and 5-second stay, treatment duration 10 minutes, and sweep frequency 10 to 130 Hz. The current intensity should be adjusted until the subject reports feeling a strong tingling sensation without causing muscle contraction. An aquatic gel should also be applied before strapping the electropads over the treatment area for smooth electrical conduction.

Absolutely! Here are the full study arms we have designed:

1. Experimental: Maitland Group
Participant Group/Arm: This group consists of participants who will receive Maitland's mobilization technique in addition to interferential therapy.
Intervention/Treatment: The participants in this group will undergo Maitland's mobilization technique, which includes various components such as distraction, anteroposterior glides, posteroanterior glides, medial glides, and lateral glides. Additionally, they will receive interferential therapy with specific parameters.

2. Active Comparator: Mulligan Group
Participant Group/Arm: This group consists of participants who will receive Mulligan's mobilization technique in addition to interferential therapy.
Intervention/Treatment: The participants in this group will undergo Mulligan's mobilization technique, which includes components such as medial mobilization with movement (MWM) for knee flexion and extension, as well as lateral mobilization with movement (MWM) for knee flexion and extension. They will also receive interferential therapy with specific parameters.

groundtruth: That's a good starting point. Based on the information you've provided, I suggest considering an experimental arm for your study. This arm could consist of participants receiving Ribociclib in combination with standard adjuvant endocrine therapy. This combination has shown efficacy in advanced breast cancer, and it would be interesting to evaluate its effectiveness in the adjuvant setting. What do you think about this suggestion?

Certainly! In the experimental arm, participants will receive Ribociclib 400 mg orally once daily on days 1 to 21 of a 28-day cycle. This will be combined with daily endocrine therapy for 36 months. For postmenopausal women, the endocrine therapy options are Letrozole 2.5 mg orally once daily continuously, Anastrozole 1 mg orally once daily continuously, or Exemestane 25 mg once daily continuously. For pre/perimenopausal women and men, the endocrine therapy options are the same as for postmenopausal women, but in combination with Goserelin or Leuprolide administered subcutaneously. What are your thoughts on this specific participant group/arm and intervention/treatment?

I'm glad you find the suggestion suitable. This arm will provide valuable data on the safety and efficacy of the combination treatment. Is there anything else you would like to discuss or any other study arms you want to design?

Definitely! Considering the effectiveness of Ribociclib with endocrine therapy, you might want to explore a comparative arm where participants receive only endocrine therapy without Ribociclib. This would allow you to evaluate the added benefit of Ribociclib in terms of invasive breast cancer-free survival. Additionally, you could consider a control arm where participants receive a placebo instead of Ribociclib. This would help determine the specific contribution of Ribociclib to the treatment outcomes. How do these suggestions sound to you?

Excellent! Including these arms will enhance the robustness of your study. To summarize, here are the full study arms for your clinical trial:

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: Ribociclib + endocrine therapy
Participants will receive Ribociclib 400 mg orally once daily on days 1-21 of a 28-day cycle, in combination with daily endocrine therapy for 36 months. The endocrine therapy options are based on the participant's menopausal status, and for pre/perimenopausal women, it will be combined with Goserelin or Leuprolide administered subcutaneously.

2. Comparative: Endocrine therapy only
Participants will receive only endocrine therapy without Ribociclib. The endocrine therapy options will be the same as in the experimental arm.

3. Control: Placebo
Participants will receive a placebo instead of Ribociclib, in addition to the same endocrine therapy options as in the experimental arm.

These study arms will allow you to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Ribociclib in comparison to endocrine therapy alone and placebo. Is there anything else I can assist you with?

Yes, there are. In the first arm we will have a smaller implant, thus obtaining a more pure result. In the second arm we will use tapered implants to investigate differences from more standard implants. In addition, tapered implants have a more controlled microbiota and are therefore more likely to have less impact on the bacterial flora. These factors will control for variability in the microbiota and also allow for more accurate findings and analysis.

The second study arm with Tapered Pro Implants allows us to compare the changes in the oral microbiome following implant placement between two different implant types. By evaluating the microbial status before and after implant placement, we can determine if there are unique microbial changes associated with Tapered Pro Implants compared to other implant types. This information will help in understanding the impact of implant design on the oral microbiome and the implications of the differences in microbial colonization between different implant types.

groundtruth: Perfect! Now, let's move on to the experimental arm. In addition to routine physical therapy, this group will receive postural and kinesthetic awareness training. How do you think we should conduct this training?

Excellent ideas! We can implement the postural and kinesthetic awareness training by having the patients perform therapeutic activities/exercises in sitting positions first, using a chair with armrests and planted feet. Then we can progress to sitting on a chair without armrests and with proper feet placement. Once the patient achieves balance in sitting on a chair, we can shift to sitting on a stool and later incorporate standing in parallel bars for balance training in independent standing. We can refer to this group as the Experimental: Routine Physical Therapy and Postural and Kinesthetic Awareness arm. Any other suggestions for this arm?

Wonderful! Now, let me summarize the study arms we have designed. We have two study arms: 

1. Active Comparator: Routine Physical Therapy
   - Participant Group/Arm: Chronic stroke patients
   - Intervention/Treatment: Routine physical therapy, including range of motion exercises (active assisted), stretching exercises, strengthening, and positioning.

2. Experimental: Routine Physical Therapy and Postural and Kinesthetic Awareness
   - Participant Group/Arm: Chronic stroke patients
   - Intervention/Treatment: Routine physical therapy, including range of motion exercises (active assisted), stretching exercises, strengthening, and positioning, along with postural and kinesthetic awareness training in front of a mirror, emphasizing proper body positioning, movements, and balance in sitting and standing positions through interoceptive and exteroceptive reinforcement.

These study arms will allow us to compare the effects of adding postural and kinesthetic awareness to routine physical therapy on static standing balance in chronic stroke patients.

Thank you for providing all the necessary details. Based on the information you've shared, I can suggest the following study arms:

1. Experimental: Cohort A - In this study arm, patients with high and undetermined risk of fibrosis (bf+) will receive adaptive breast cancer radiotherapy using ETHOS. The intervention for this arm is Treatment ETHOS radiotherapy.

2. Active Comparator: Cohort B - In this study arm, patients with low risk of fibrosis (bf-) will receive conventional intensity-modulated radiotherapy (IMRT). The intervention for this arm is Conventional IMRT.

These study arms will allow us to compare the outcomes of adaptive radiotherapy with ETHOS in high-risk patients (Cohort A) to conventional IMRT in low-risk patients (Cohort B). By assessing the efficacy and safety of adaptive radiotherapy in hypersensitive patients with high locoregional risk breast cancer, we can evaluate the potential benefits of personalized treatment and determine its impact on locoregional control and toxicity outcomes.

In Cohort A, the target volume for adaptive radiotherapy using ETHOS (Treatment ETHOS radiotherapy) is defined as PTV = CTV + 2 mm (except for IMC with 5mm), excluding 5mm beneath the skin. On the other hand, in Cohort B, the target volume for conventional IMRT is defined as PTV = CTV + 7mm, excluding 5mm beneath the skin. These target volume differences are designed to accommodate the specific needs of each treatment modality and the risk profiles of the patients in each cohort.

[*]Hi, A single-center study proposing to enroll 100 subjects over the course of 24 months. Participants will be recruited from an outpatient hypertensive population, presenting for routine blood pressure monitoring. Exclusion criteria for the study include: history of antihypertensive and antiangiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)/.angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) use. Participants satisfying eligibility requirements will be randomized to one of two study groups. The "drug" group will follow the protocol for titration of antihypertensive medication to achieve a goal mean blood pressure of less than 130/80 mmHg, in accordance with standard American Heart Association guidelines. The "control" group will employ a 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) and 48-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM) recording to assess changes in blood pressure variability over a 48-hour period. Assessments will be obtained at baseline, 3, 6, and 12 months and yearly thereafter for duration of the 24-month study period.
groundtruth: Absolutely. The second study arm, labeled as "Drug: Low BPV Regimen," focuses on implementing the low BPV regimen in participants who are in the highest decile of BPV. Each participant's physician will invite them to complete a 48-hour ABPM, followed by cross-titration from their current antihypertensive regimen to the low BPV regimen. The low BPV regimen consists of Amlodipine and Indapamide as the primary medications. I would suggest starting patients on Amlodipine 5mg daily, with uptitration to 10mg daily to achieve a goal systolic blood pressure (SBP) of less than 130 mmHg. Indapamide should be added at 1.25mg daily and increased to 2.5mg daily if needed to meet the target SBP. Other antihypertensive medications should be discontinued as the SBP target is reached. Patients not meeting the target SBP on maximally tolerated Amlodipine and Indapamide will be suggested to have a long-acting angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)/ angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) added to their therapy. After one week at the target SBP on the low-BPV regimen, patients will complete another 48-hour ABPM for evaluation of the change in BPV.

Certainly! Here are the full study arms for your clinical trial:

Study Arm 1:
Participant Group/Arm: Other: Ambulatory Blood Pressure Monitor (ABPM)
Intervention/Treatment: Drug: Low BPV Regimen
Description: Participants on antihypertensive pharmacotherapy in the highest decile of BPV will undergo a 48-hour ABPM to determine baseline BPV. Subsequently, their primary care physicians will be guided through titrations to antihypertensive medications to a low BPV regimen. The optional sub-study will test the hypothesis that ABPM and SKNA data can be simultaneously captured and that BPV will be positively correlated with SKNA. Participants in the sub-study will be fitted with a single patch ECG for the analysis of SKNA.

Study Arm 2:
Participant Group/Arm: Drug: Low BPV Regimen
Intervention/Treatment: Each participant's physician will invite them to complete a 48-hour ABPM, followed by cross-titration from their current antihypertensive regimen to a low BPV regimen consisting of Amlodipine and Indapamide. Patients will be suggested to start with Amlodipine 5mg daily, with uptitration to 10mg daily to achieve a goal SBP of less than 130 mmHg. Indapamide will be suggested to be added at 1.25mg daily and increased to 2.5mg daily, if needed. Other antihypertensive medications will be discontinued as the SBP target is reached. Patients not meeting the target SBP on maximally tolerated Amlodipine and Indapamide will be suggested to have a long-acting ACE/ARB added to their therapy. After one week at the target SBP on the low-BPV regimen, patients will complete another 48-hour ABPM for evaluation of the change in BPV.

1. Experimental: Conservative Treatment (CT)
   - Participant Group/Arm: Patients receiving conservative treatment (CT) including hotpack, TENS, ultrasound, and home exercise programs.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Conservative treatment (HP, US, TENS) was applied for 3 weeks, with 5 sessions per week, a total of 15 sessions.

2. Experimental: Instrument Assisted Soft Tissue Mobilization (IASTM)
   - Participant Group/Arm: Patients receiving conservative treatment (CT) along with instrument-assisted soft tissue mobilization (IASTM) therapy.
   - Intervention/Treatment: IASTM was performed only on the neck and upper back muscles on the aching side using the sweep technique on the origo and insertion lines. A total of 6 sessions were applied, two sessions per week for 3 weeks. Conservative treatment (HP, US, TENS) was also applied for 3 weeks, with 5 sessions per week, a total of 15 sessions.

3. Experimental: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Therapy (ESWT)
   - Participant Group/Arm: Patients receiving conservative treatment (CT) along with extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT).
   - Intervention/Treatment: ESWT therapy was applied on the muscle with an active trigger point, at 1.5-2.0 bar pressure, at 10 Hz frequency, 2000 beats in each session, twice a week, for a total of 6 sessions. Conservative treatment (HP, US, TENS) was also applied for 3 weeks, with 5 sessions per week, a total of 15 sessions.

Absolutely. For the pulmonary vein isolation, a catheter ablation technique will be used to create electrical isolation around the pulmonary veins, preventing pulmonary vein ectopy from triggering atrial fibrillation. This is a crucial step in comparing the efficacy of ablation versus cardioversion in reducing AF recurrence. As for the DC cardioversion, it will be performed if the patient is still in AF at the end of the pulmonary vein isolation procedure. The implantable loop recorder, known as the Reveal device, will be inserted in the pre-pectoral position under the skin with local anesthetic and sedation at least a week before randomization. It will provide continuous recording of the heart rhythm and rate, which can be downloaded via a home monitoring system to establish the primary endpoint of the study. Lastly, two femoral sheaths (7Fr) will be inserted using ultrasound guidance under local anesthetic. These sheaths will serve as the access route for cardiac catheter insertion during the procedure. Do you have any questions or suggestions regarding these interventions?

In addition, a sham procedure will be performed after randomization, along with intermittent phrenic nerve pacing. This sham procedure, along with the use of intermittent phrenic nerve pacing, serves as a control group to compare the outcomes of the active intervention arm and assess the specific impact of pulmonary vein isolation in reducing AF recurrence.      - Procedure: DC Cardioversion
       - DC cardioversion (DCCV) is used to treat irregular heart rhythms (commonly atrial fibrillation). The procedure involves sedation or anesthesia and placement of electrodes on the chest. An electrical impulse is passed across the electrodes to return the heart rhythm to normal.

Pharmacomechanical versus Finite Element Analysis in Evaluation of the Most Suitable Point of Fixation for Zygomaticomaxillary Complex Fractures.
Pharma-mechanical or Finite Element Analysis in evaluation of the most suitable point of fixation for Zygomaticomaxillary Complex Fractures.
This is a randomized controlled trial on patients with complex zygomaticomaxillary fractures that would be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to either undergo pharma-mechanical evaluation of the most suitable point of fixation by finite elements or to pharma-mechanical evaluation using CBCT-scan and the same finite elements. This group will serve as the control, or best-practices, and the other half will undergo the experimental intervention. The end-points of the trial will be the functional outcome on the McGill-Palmer-36 (MP36) index and the rate of non-union / malunion of the fracture using radiographic images.

Thank you for providing all the necessary information. Based on the details you've shared, I would suggest designing a single study arm for your trial. This arm can be named "Experimental: finite arm." The participant group/arm would undergo the procedure of Zygomaticomaxillary fracture repair. We would start by using a cone beam CT scan to create a 3D scanned image of the Zygomaticomaxillary complex fracture. These 3D images will be introduced to finite element (FA) software to evaluate stresses, micromotion, and life time for each model. The analysis will help us determine the best point of fixation for the fracture. After applying this point of fixation on the patient, we would perform another round of finite element analysis to verify the results. This arm will provide valuable insights into the role of finite element analysis in selecting the optimal point of fixation for Zygomaticomaxillary complex fractures.

3.2.3 Specifying the sample size in the study protocol
3.2.3.1 Determining the sample size
To calculate the sample size for the study, we need to estimate the following:
- The standard deviation of the continuous outcome variable
Either based on previous research (if available) or based on pilot data
- The mean difference in the change of the continuous outcome variable between the two treatment groups
- The standard deviation of the change in the continuous outcome variable between the two treatment groups
The formula for the sample size uses the mean difference estimate and the standard deviation of the change in the outcome variable. A sample size of 120 will likely to give 80% power (to detect a real effect if the average treatment effect is 0.60, with a standard deviation of 0.6 and a significance level of 0.05. You may need to adjust sample size for continuity of covariates, if relevant.
For more information, review the "Determining the sample size" and "Considerations for the calculation of sample size" sections on the Sample size webpage.
3.2.3.2 Determining the number of treatment groups: factorial design
The sample size may need to be slightly larger due to the interaction between the two independent variables. In such cases, you will need an additional four treatment groups:
- Control + Nordic walking
- Control + deadlifting
- Deadlifting + Nordic walking
- Control + deadlifting + Nordic walking (interaction effect)

CET and LIFU in the third arm: CET stands for cognitive endurance training, a method of improving the cognitive abilities of the brain, and LIFU is used as before. An important consideration when designing the study is naming. In this case, the treatment (vaccine) arm is the "experimental" arm and the control (placebo) is named the "experimental" arm. This naming is backwards from the convention in a medical context, but is appropriate in this case because the intent is to test the effect of the treatment, not the effect of something else on the treatment.
(Also the placebo, or "control" arm gets the designation "experimental" because it is a comparison against a not yet existing intervention, but in general the controls would be better named the "standard of care" or "disease progression" arm because the goal is to contrast progression under that condition.)

The consumption of probiotics/prebiotics is confirmed by stool elastase-α-galactosidase negative faeces samples. After 12 weeks, participants will undergo the same blood collection schedule as in the run-in phase, except with a 14-day washout period before the post collection. Thank you for the information. Based on the details provided, I suggest the following study arms:

1. Active Comparator: Tideglusib
Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes participants who are randomized to receive Tideglusib 1g orally daily.
Intervention/Treatment: Participants in this arm will be receiving the active drug, Tideglusib, which is a glycogen synthase kinase-3 β inhibitor. This arm is necessary to evaluate the potential therapeutic efficacy of Tideglusib in genotype positive arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy. By comparing the outcomes of participants receiving Tideglusib to those receiving placebo, researchers can determine if Tideglusib is effective in treating arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy.

2. Placebo Comparator: Placebo
Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes participants who are randomized to receive a matching placebo 1g orally daily.
Intervention/Treatment: Participants in this arm will be receiving a placebo, which is an inactive substance with no therapeutic effect. This arm is necessary to serve as a control group for comparison with the active drug arm. By comparing the outcomes of participants receiving placebo to those receiving Tideglusib, researchers can assess the specific effects of Tideglusib on arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy, without the influence of any potential placebo effects. This helps ensure that any observed effects of Tideglusib are truly due to the drug's mechanism of action and not due to other factors.

Based on the details you've given me, I would suggest designing a study arm specifically for patients with renal failure who will undergo sleeve gastrectomy. This arm can include the interventions you mentioned earlier, such as the 6-minute walk distance evaluation, activity monitoring, continuous glucose monitor, blood pressure monitoring, body composition scan, mixed meal testing, and quality of life assessment.

Certainly! The 6-minute walk distance evaluation will provide valuable information on the patient's physical fitness and endurance, which is important for assessing their overall health status and potential post-operative outcomes. Activity monitoring through an Actigraph will help researchers understand the patient's daily activity levels and patterns, which can impact their recovery and long-term success following sleeve gastrectomy. Continuous glucose monitoring is crucial for monitoring glucose levels in patients with renal failure, as they are at higher risk for metabolic complications. Blood pressure monitoring is essential for patients with renal failure, as hypertension is a common comorbidity. Body composition scan will provide detailed information on the patient's body composition, including fat percentage, muscle mass, and visceral fat, which are important factors to consider in the context of sleeve gastrectomy and renal failure. Mixed meal testing will assess the patient's metabolic response to a standardized meal, providing insights into their nutritional status and potential post-operative dietary considerations. Quality of life assessment is crucial for evaluating the impact of sleeve gastrectomy on the patient's overall well-being and satisfaction with the procedure.

Great! Here is the study arm design for patients with renal failure undergoing sleeve gastrectomy:
- Participant Group/Arm: Renal Failure Sleeve Gastrectomy
- Intervention/Treatment: 
   - Diagnostic Test: 6 minutes walk distance
      - Subjects walk as far as possible for 6 minutes at a self-selected pace, and the total distance walked will be recorded
   - Behavioral: Activity Monitor
      - Subjects will wear an Actigraph on their wrist like a watch for up to 10 days at home to monitor activity.
   - Behavioral: Continuous Glucose Monitor
      - Subjects will collect glucose values in the fluid under their skin for up to 10 days at home.
   - Behavioral: Blood Pressure Monitoring
      - Subjects will monitor their blood pressure at home for 10 consecutive days 3 times a day
   - Diagnostic Test: Blood Pressure Monitoring
      - 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring
   - Diagnostic Test: Body Composition Scan
      - Measure of body fat percentage, skeletal muscle mass, body water, and visceral fat.
   - Diagnostic Test: Mixed meal testing
      - Subjects will consume 6 ml/kg body weight of Boost, up to a maximum of 360 ml, within 5 min
   - Diagnostic Test: Quality of Life
      - Subject will complete Quality of Life Questionnaire

I recommend semi-structured interviews at around 3 and 12 months. This will allow us to assess the changes in needs and preferences over time and identify areas where the existing care pathway may need revision.

The semi-structured interview should include questions exploring patients' perspectives on the following and similar areas: 1. Understanding of the diagnosis and treatment options 2. Preference for and preferences between treatment options 3. Satisfaction with treatment decisions 4. Satisfaction with care coordination 5. Satisfaction with communication with their healthcare team 6. Ability to ask questions and get answers 7. Preferences for follow-up appointments and follow-up care 8. Preferences for future treatment options and overall satisfaction with care 9. Factors that helped or hindered their ability to adhere to the prescribed treatment 10. Any additional recommendations or feedback They can also be asked to rate their satisfaction and treatment options on a Likert scale. You can elaborate on these questions based on your specific research question and the areas you are exploring.

For the intervention/treatment arm, you could include a second opinion or mock surgery.  This could help in improving the knowledge of the disease and help in making a decision.  Additionally, this will boost the confidence of the patient as he/she takes an active part in making a decision regarding the surgery. By this, chances of revision surgery can also be reduced.

For the second study arm, we can develop a quasi-experimental study evaluating the role of acupuncture as a supportive therapy for head-neck cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. The treatment/intervention in this arm could be "Acupuncture for patients with high-risk cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma of the head-neck region, not receiving regular multidisciplinary care" and we can use the same semi-structured interview to evaluate its impact.

The intervention/treatment could be "High-risk patients with head-and-neck cutaneous squamous cell carcinomas receive standardized care plus an additional one-on-one interview per week for ten weeks, aimed at establishing a supportive relationship and emotional support." The treatment arms for the trial are NALIRIFOX with or without radiotherapy. Arm A receives NALIRIFOX alone, and Arm B receives NALIRIFOX and radiation therapy. Both treatment arms involve a 4-month treatment regimen with a 6-month assessment after completion of treatment. Treatment duration for Arm A is 12 weeks (1 cycle 30 mg/m2 IVF every 3 weeks) with or without concomitant oxaliplatin given on days 1, 8, 29 of the first and second cycle. Arm B participants will receive oral capecitabine (825 mg/m2, BID) and oxaliplatin (85 mg/m2, D1, 8, 29 every 3 weeks). Once the tumor volume increases to 2 cm or greater, radiation therapy is administered in a standard fractionated course until the tumor volume reaches <2.0 cm. The radiation regimen consists of 50.4 Gy in 18 fractions every other day and may be boosted to a dose of 36 Gy in 18 fractions. Radiation will be initiated after completion of NALIRIFOX and will not commence until there is documentation of a 50% decrease in tumor bulk. Is there a specific reason 5-FU is given on day 1 and 15 but not on day 8, the day of irinotecan?” 

Thank you for your question. We thought it best to give 5-FU on day 1 and 15 as this is the day irinotecan is administered. Nalirifox is given continuously over 90 minutes while irinotecan is given over the course of 240 minutes so it made sense to delay a short period of 5-FU administration to avoid drug wash out. It would also not be optimal to be giving 5-FU for 90 minutes followed by 120 minutes of irinotecan. 

With regards your question about a third comparator arm, studies have shown that irinotecan + oxaliplatin (IROX) is equally efficacious or slightly more efficacious than FOLFOX. If a trial wished to incorporate a third comparator arm it would be reasonable to administer irinotecan alone on days 1, 8, 15 and 22 along with leucovorin only on days 1, 8, 15 and 22. Patients will receive neoadjuvant chemotherapy for 4 months. Patients will undergo a CT scan at 8 weeks and 16 weeks after the start of neoadjuvant chemotherapy to assess treatment response. Patients without disease progression will then undergo AD-XRT for 15 to 25 fractions (3 to 5 weeks). Patient's whose disease is deemed resectable based on their re-evaluating imaging, will be recommended surgical intervention with consideration for laparotomy or laparoscopy if deemed appropriate at multidisciplinary cancer conference review. | Drug: NALIRIFOX
* Patients will receive NALIRIFOX for a total of 4 months. NALIRIFOX will be administered on days 1 and 15 of a 4-week cycle for 4 cycles until completion of therapy, intolerable toxicity, or until the development of criteria for removal from the study.~Liposomal irinotecan: 50 mg/m2 IV over the course of 90 minutes (±10 minutes) on days 1 and 15 of every 4-week cycle.~Oxaliplatin: 60 mg/m2 IV over the course of 120 minutes (±10 minutes) on days 1 and 15 of every 4-week cycle.~Leucovorin: 400 mg/m2 IV over the course of 30 minutes (±5 minutes) on days 1 and 15 of every 4-week cycle.~5-FU: 2400 mg/m2 IV over the course of 46 hours (±60 minutes) on days 1 and 15 of every 4-week cycle
Combination Product: AD-XRT and Capecitabine
* The interval between completion of induction chemotherapy and initiation of AD-XRT will be 2-6 weeks. The patient will be concurrently treated with capecitabine (1000-1500 mg flat BID PO Monday to Friday) with radiation, as per standard dosing regimens at MSK.
